DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF THE HON. SIR KENNETH ANDERSON, KBE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House expresses its deep regret at the death of the Hon. Sir Kenneth McColl Anderson, KBE, who died on 29 March 1985, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service, and tenders its profound sympathy to his wife and family.

Sir Kenneth Anderson was, in fact, born at sea in Australian waters approaching Adelaide on 11 October 1909. As a young man he enlisted in the Australian Imperial Force on 2 July 1940 and rose to the rank of lieutenant before becoming a prisoner of the Japanese. He remained a prisoner of war for over three years, enduring enormous hardship not only in the infamous Changi prison but also on the Burma-Thailand railway. His service to his country did not end with the war. He served his wartime colleagues as a director of the Ryde District Soldiers Hospital for a period of 25 years, including over four distinguished years as its Chairman. He remained a life-long member of the Returned Services League.

Sir Kenneth's parliamentary service commenced in the New South Wales Parliament in 1950 as the member for Ryde. He was elected to Federal Parliament in 1953, serving for 22 years before his retirement. His career was distinguished. He served as a Minister to five Prime Ministers: Sir Robert Menzies, Mr Harold Holt, Sir John McEwen, Sir John Gorton and Sir William McMahon. He was, variously, Minister for Customs and Excise, Minister for Supply and Minister for Health. In addition, he served his Party as Leader of the Government in the Senate from 1968 to 1972.
Sir Kenneth's 22 years as a senator were marked by diligence and conscientiousness. In his maiden speech, on 16 September 1953, he said:

I came here to serve . . . I set about serving on 2 July, 1940 and I shall not turn back now. In common with other honourable senators, I just want to do whatever is within my power to help my fellow man.

Sir Kenneth fully honoured that pledge in his long career. He was a distinguished Australian who gave much to both this Parliament and his country. On behalf of the Government, Mr Speaker, I extend to his widow and his family our sincerest sympathy and regret at the loss of this very fine Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the motion of condolence moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Sir Kenneth Anderson was a man of enormous courage, integrity and energy who served his country, as the Prime Minister has indicated, with great distinction both in war and in peace. He rose from private to lieutenant in the 8th Division, fighting of course in the ill-fated Malayan campaign. Imprisoned in Changi, he also suffered and survived the horrors of the infamous Burma-Thailand railway, the construction of which under the most dreadful circumstances saw the deaths of so many brave Australian soldiers.

SPEECH.PARA: At war's end he devoted his life to the service of the community and also to the cause of liberalism in local, regional and finally national government. The Prime Minister has spoken of his service to his own community in Ryde. Kenneth Anderson's father had three times been mayor of that municipality, and in l949 he also became mayor and at the same time a member of the Sydney regional administrative body. After serving as a member of the Lower House in New South Wales for three years, he became a senator in l953 and served with distinction until l975. As the Prime Minister has said, he was a distinguished Minister in three portfolios-Customs, Supply and Health-and was also for three years Government Leader in the Senate as well as being active in many of its committees. I had the honour to serve as a Minister with Ken Anderson in the late l960s and early l970s, and then of course through our period in Opposition.

When he retired to what should have been a well-earned retirement, he remained more active than many people his junior. In l976, at the age of 65, he returned to politics as President of the New South Wales Division of the Liberal Party of Australia and helped lay the foundations for its present new vigour and effectiveness. In every aspect of his life, whether as a soldier, as a Minister, as a director for 25 years of the Ryde District Soldiers Hospital or as President of his local branch of the Returned Services League, Ken Anderson was dedicated to the service of his fellow Australians. He went about this service, as all who knew him were constantly aware, in a quiet and persuasive manner but with a quiet and a determined approach. Ken Anderson was possessed of a keen mind which accompanied that quiet manner and therefore he was able to lead by example. He was, in the very breadth of his service to our country, greatly respected. As the Prime Minister said, in Ken Anderson's maiden speech he indicated that he sought really nothing more than to serve his fellow man and in that he succeeded, and succeeded greatly. He was a fine, courageous man of very great character indeed, and my Party and this Parliament owe him a significant debt. He will be greatly missed and I extend our deepest sympathy to Lady Anderson and the rest of his family.

I repeat: I ask the Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, to put aside the rhetoric. In those circumstances we will ask that all the industrial action be put aside. If we sit down together, we can resolve this matter.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Honourable members are aware of recent Press speculation about a tour of South Africa by a team of Australian cricketers. Can the Prime Minister indicate the Government's attitude to such a possibility?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of these Press reports. I do not know whether they are correct but I certainly hope that they are not. I am very pleased to be able to say that this Government, in its approach to sporting relations with South Africa, has built upon the very sound foundations that preceded it under the Whitlam and the Fraser Governments in regard to opposing the obscene and repugnant system of apartheid. I have paid tribute before and I pay it again not only to the Whitlam Government but also to the Fraser Government for their attitudes in this respect. Over the past 15 years, I believe, Australian sportsmen and sportswomen and Australian sporting bodies have had a proud record in the shunning of sporting contacts with South Africa. I believe their attitude has been exemplary. I also commend in this respect the attitude of the Prime Minister of New Zealand, Mr Lange, in attempting to dissuade the New Zealand Rugby Union from sending a team to play in South Africa, and I look forward to discussing that matter with him tomorrow. In view particularly of the tragic violence and loss of life which is currently occurring in South Africa because of the apartheid system, it would be shameful if reports that a team of rebel Australian cricketers was preparing to visit South Africa turned out to be true.

ANSWER.PARA: I conclude by saying that, notwithstanding the very considerable financial rewards which it is alleged are associated with this offer, I earnestly request any Australian cricketers who are contemplating accepting such an offer to think about the principles involved. I ask them to think about the comfort that they would give to a racist regime by accepting that offer. I ask them to think about the plight of blacks in South Africa. I ask them to think about the reputations of themselves and of their country and to reject any offers they may have received.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to the Prime Minister's non-answer to the question from the Leader of the Opposition--

I find it difficult to understand why the Premier of Queensland has rejected it if his concern is to prevent this kind of industrial action taking place. That constructive proposal has been put. It has been rejected. The Prime Minister has again said today that it is still on offer. The Premier of Queensland can, if he wishes, change his mind, and we will sit down in constructive discussion with him. Let me say also that it is our understanding that in those discussions the trade union movement would be prepared to make proposals to the Queensland Government about the establishment of a settlement of disputes procedure in the electricity industry and that the ACTU would be prepared to endorse the adherence to that procedure by the Queensland unions. —Call your thugs off.
—They have not adhered to their word.
—So you call the strike off.
—I warn the honourable member for O'Connor. I remind the honourable member that this is the second time today he has been warned. I call the Minister.

—I think the difference in this situation is that the ACTU is saying that it is prepared to guarantee that there would be adherence to some settlement of disputes procedure; so this is a quite different situation from that which the Queensland Government may have experienced in the past. It is regrettable in the extreme that the Queensland Government does not seem to be prepared to look at a constructive settlement. As I said earlier, there was almost a constructive settlement in the State Industrial Commission at the time when he called on the state of emergency and then rejected two recommendations from the State Industrial Commission, which recommendations would have settled the dispute on the spot and would have led to none of the subsequent industrial action which has taken place and none of the unhappy period of extremely undemocratic legislation which has been passed through the Queensland Parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: It is quite clear that this Government has been thoroughly constructive. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has his attention been drawn to an article in the Brisbane Sunday Mail of 7 April in which the journalist Sylvia da Costa-Roque suggested that $100m is being spent in aid for the sugar industry in Bangladesh? Will the Minister inform the House of the extent of government aid to Bangladesh? Has the journalist wildly misled the Queensland public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the article but a number of people have drawn my attention to what they have declared to be its content. Apparently the article did declare that $100m had been spent on developing the sugar industry in Bangladesh and implied that this was at the cost of the Queensland sugar industry, which is in serious difficulty. The facts are that $18m is to be spent over several years on a program to improve the sugar industry in Bangladesh. The program will conclude in December this year. This year, the concluding year of the program, an amount of $6.8m is being spent. Of that, $6.2m will be spent in Queensland acquiring equipment and machinery to improve the operation of sugar mills in Bangladesh. The remainder of the $6.8m will be spent on Australian technical experts and advisers working in Bangladesh.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that the people of Bangladesh require a substantial improvement in the energy content of their nutritional intake, and sugar makes a valuable contribution in that respect. As I understand the situation, even with a substantial improvement in the production of sugar in Bangladesh, the Bangladeshi people will provide sufficient domestic demand to consume that sugar. It will not therefore be a problem concerning the Australian export of sugar in a very difficult international market. Bangladesh does not represent an important market outlet for Australian sugar. Finally, although I have not read the article, I know personally and well the journalist concerned and she is generally a journalist of the highest standards. Obviously the information was wrong in the first place and that is most unfortunate.

It was the Queensland Government's action which in the first place brought about the situation whereby action such as that contemplated by the ACTU is likely to occur.

ANSWER.PARA: That is not to say that we support the action but we understand the situation that has brought it about. It is something for which the Queensland Government must be held substantially responsible. If it wants to adopt a confrontationist approach to industrial relations, which is obviously its desire, it will inevitably reap the harvest of that in terms of some kind of retaliatory action.

That is what happens with confrontationist industrial relations. That is what happened under the previous Fraser Government with the various attempts by that Government to bring about industrial peace by draconian legislation and by using various legislative approaches to try to hammer unions into submission. The usual result is to get the opposite reaction. That is why in this situation we can see that the Queensland Government must be held substantially responsible for the action that it has taken and that is likely to take place.

It would be wise for the Opposition to get its facts right in this whole matter before raising points which are quite wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Honourable members will be aware of the Government's ongoing commitment to assist first home buyers and to attack housing-related poverty and the Government's remarkable achievements in both these areas. Honourable members will also be aware of the strength of recovery in the housing and construction industry. This Government is proud of its housing record. When we came to office, home construction was at a 20-year low. Dwelling commencements in 1982-83 were only 105,000, leaving a large, pent-up demand for housing. The Opposition was happy to preside over these conditions. This Government was not. We set about stimulating activity through the first home owners scheme and assistance to public housing. Commencements built up to 137,000 in 1983-84. The Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry now expects 147,000 commencements in 1984-85. Commencements substantially exceeded the Indicative Planning Council's estimate of underlying demand in these years because our measures had enabled aggregate pent-up demand to be run off. Thanks to the direct stimulus which we applied, that process is now largely complete. It is now appropriate to achieve a level of activity consistent with the underlying trends. The Indicative Planning Council forecast of commencements in 1985-86 is currently 139,000. So we are successfully striving to achieve not only growth, but also stability in the housing construction industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Employment in the housing industry has increased. Since the Labor Government came to office over 55,000 jobs have been created in the industry. Of course, many more jobs have been created in other areas involved in the housing market-the finance industry, real estate and in the furniture and white goods industries. The Government's policies are designed to sustain a high level of activity in the housing industry, while also supporting continued economic recovery more generally. As the Government has made clear on many occasions, sustained economic recovery calls for firm action to progressively rein in the Budget deficit. This has been recognised in the Government's budgetary commitments, in particular, its commitment to bring down the deficit in money terms in 1985-86. A lower deficit and a lower public sector borrowing requirement will ease pressure on interest rates-a matter of particular importance to the housing industry. In accordance with this responsible economic approach, the first home owners scheme will be amended. The maximum benefit available under each payment option and each dependant category will be reduced by $1000 for applicants contracting for the purchase or construction of then home from midnight tonight, 16 April 1985. This means, for example, that a family unit with two or more dependant children will receive up to $6000 over five years, compared with the previous benefit of $7000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame on you. The promise lasted 16 weeks.

—It is surprising how the Opposition urges us to bring down the deficit and yet as we make this very first statement in the 1985-86 budgetary context, it is criticising us for it. It just shows that, if faced with very hard decisions to make, this Opposition would not be able to make them.

SPEECH.PARA: I see that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is walking out. No doubt he does not want to stay and hear how we are going to bring down the deficit a little. This decision will produce estimated savings of $25m from costs of the program in 1985-86. We now expect to appropriate $290m to assist 82,500 applicants. I stress that, contrary to some ill-founded rumours, the scheme will continue to help the same categories of people whom it has helped in the past, and it will continue to provide welcome stimulation to the building industry and to employment prospects. All applicants who contracted to purchase or construct a home before midnight on 16 April 1985 will continue to be eligible for benefits at the previous levels, regardless of when they lodge their applications. I also wish to assure the House that no person currently eligible for assistance will be excluded from the scheme, and no person presently receiving monthly subsidies will have that benefit cut. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a revised schedule of benefits under each payment option.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House.

SPEECH.PARA: I will be writing to housing and finance institutions, estate agents, builders and others active in the housing industry setting out full details of the change. The decision to reduce the benefit has been taken as part of our 1985-86 Budget deliberations, but I am announcing it now to dispel speculation about the scheme's abolition, which is of concern to intending eligible first home buyers and to the building industry. Announcing this decision now will also enable the changes to cover the full 1985-86 financial year, consistent with the Government's approach to general budgetary reform. It is particularly important that the decision be seen in the context of the Government's approach to the formulation of the 1985-86 Budget. It provides tangible evidence that the targets the Government has set itself in this respect will be met. The Government is concerned that the integrity of the 1985-86 Budget appropriation is assured. Later today I will introduce a Bill to effect a number of machinery changes to the First Home Owners Act, amongst which is a provision to ensure that in 1985-86 expenditure on the first home owners scheme can be held to this Budget appropriation-that is $290m. Following the passage of this Bill there will be no further changes to the first home owners scheme in 1985-86.

I remind honourable members that when we first announced our commitment to a first home owners scheme in our 1982 national housing platform we promised a grant of up to $5,000. Following our election in March 1983, after consultation with the industry, and given the urgent need to stimulate housing industry activity and to create jobs, the maximum grant was increased to $7,000. Since then the first home owners scheme has proved spectacularly successful. In the first nine months of operation in 1983-84, 55,000 households were assisted at a cost of $141m.

In the 1984-85 Budget we anticipated that a further 80,000 households would be assisted at a cost of $265m. In fact, the popularity of the scheme outstripped expectations, and in February this year an additional $25m was allocated to first home owners scheme funding for 1984-85, bringing funding for this financial year to $290m and increasing the number of households to be assisted this year to 87,000. The change I have announced today should not reduce the scheme's total expenditure or the number to be assisted in 1984-85. So, by the end of June 1985, the first home owners scheme will have helped approximately 142,000 Australian households buy their first homes, with $431m paid to recipients. In 1985-86 we estimate that a further 82,500 will be assisted. Thus, by the end of 1985-86 financial year, nearly 225,000 Australian households will have received a first home owners grant-a spectacular figure indeed.

Madam Deputy Speaker, I am pleased to advise honourable members that the scheme has also kept thousands of low income home seekers off public housing waiting lists. I again remind the House that in 1984-85, total Federal and State funding for public housing will be almost $1,600m-a record even in real terms. The Federal Government's direct allocation of $623.3m is in stark contrast to the $264.1m allocated by the previous Government in its last full year of office. There is also a strong link between the Government's first home owners scheme and assistance under the home purchase assistance component of the Commonwealth-State housing agreement. Persons receiving this home purchase assistance under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement can also receive first home owners scheme assistance if eligible under the guidelines of that scheme.

Madam Deputy Speaker, as a responsible Government, we are prepared to take the necessary hard and tough decisions to reduce the Budget deficit, while maintaining building activity at a sustainable level. That is what this move today does; it meets both requirements. The Opposition is absolutely stuck. It wants to support the business community in arguing for a reduction in the total Budget deficit, yet it is not prepared to take explicit, specific individual action to achieve that end.

In recognition of the important role of housing in the continuing economic recovery, changes to the first home owners scheme have been kept to a minimum. I believe that housing industry organisations and the people of Australia will support our efforts to reduce the Budget deficit, while at the same time directing available Budget resources to a continuing first home owners scheme. TALK.START.PARA: —the Hawke socialist Government has quite disgracefully betrayed the prospective home owners of Australia. It has broken a solemn election pledge, just 16 weeks after the election. With absolute premeditation, the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West), who now flees from the chamber, in company with the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Hawke), has torn up the election pledges. This is a shameful betrayal of many thousands of decent Australian first home owners who were conned into voting for Mr Hawke on l December. I wonder how many of these people would have voted the way they did if they had known what was in store for them at the hands of this deceitful Government just four months later. I say bluntly, on behalf of the Opposition, on behalf of the housing industry and on behalf of the people of Australia, that the Prime Minister and the Minister for Housing and Construction have grossly deceived the industry, the people and the prospective first home purchasers.

Madam Deputy Speaker, you have followed the housing industry very closely for many years. We have just heard the Minister say that these cuts will not really have any bad effect, yet the Minister would surely be aware that as recently as yesterday the Institute of Urban Studies pointed out very forcibly to him and the Government that the first home owners scheme was still not giving sufficient help to the needy. I would like to know where all those members of the Australian Labor Party who say they are genuinely concerned about public housing and the needy will be in this debate. Rather than increase the assistance under the first home owners scheme, this wicked and deceitful Government has chopped $40.37m off it. Look at what it has done to the applicants. As from tonight, the applicants will find their grants cut by as much as 14.29 per cent. That will mean that thousands of decent young Australian men and women who were hoping to get the first home owners grant in order to get themselves into a house this year will now be told by this heartless and deceitful Government: 'Bad luck. We used the con and the promise to get your vote and l6 weeks later we tore up our solemn pledge'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—It is a shameful thing. I note the presence of the honourable member for Berowra, whose concern in this area is well known on both sides of the House. This is the most disgraceful broken promise in the housing area that I can bring to mind in eight years in State Parliament and 10 years in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: It is only a few weeks ago that the dogs were barking that the first home owners scheme was going to get the chop. Barely two weeks ago the Prime Minister of Australia delivered a major speech to the Twentieth National Housing Industry Convention and he did something very interesting. He left out the nasty parts of his speech. The delegates to that convention had to read the nasty bits in the newspapers the very next day. Of course, the Prime Minister did not want to read out at the convention what his wicked Government had in mind. Oh, no-the Prime Minister gave all the commercials, and these can be found in a copy of his speech, which is freely available. On page 4 there are four glowing paragraphs about what a marvellous thing the first home owners scheme is. Then we come to the interesting words that he just happened not to read out. It was said later by one of his aides that he ran out of time. If he has limited time in future, I suggest that the best advice to him is: 'Do not worry about the good parts; have the guts to tell the industry and the people of Australia the bad parts'. What he did not read out was this:
It must be recognised, nevertheless, that no Government program can remain unchanged indefinitely, especially when the circumstances in which that program was introduced are changing.

There was the warning. He did not tell the delegates that. They had to read it in the newspapers the next day. The Prime Minister of Australia did not have the courage and the guts to tell the Twentieth National Housing Industry Convention the bad news that was about to come. Now we can see what it is.

The Minister for Housing and Construction should resign or should be sacked on two grounds. He should be sacked, first for bringing this disgraceful statement into the Parliament and, secondly, because this is the first of the new pre-Budget announcements and it was leaked to the Press. I ask the House what happens to Treasurers and Ministers who let Budget decisions get leaked to the Press? In today's Australian there is the story on the front page. Sure, there is a slight discrepancy in the figures, but the guts of it is there. What an insult to this Parliament-to members of this House and members of the Senate-that we should read what the Minister was going to say in Parliament on page 1 of today's Australian. I predicted in December last year that the Minister and the Prime Minister would make as great a mess of housing and construction as they jointly made of immigration last year. That prediction is well on line.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wait until the Government gets started on the economy.

—Oh, indeed! The Prime Minister not only missed out three paragraphs, but also sat with the National President of the Housing Industry Association, Mr John Graham, knowing that Mr Graham had, just a few minutes earlier, said these words:

SPEECH.PARA: No matter how loud the critics cry, the first home owners scheme should not and must not be abandoned or tampered with. Not only will the continuance of the scheme enable the Government to pursue a very worthwhile social objective, but it will encourage a much needed degree of stability in what has hitherto been a far too volatile industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—That was said by the President of the Housing Industry Association, Mr John Graham. The Prime Minister sat with Mr Graham and with the Federal directors and did not have the courage to tell them what he and his Government had in store. The Minister was at that function and he knows that what I say is correct. The Minister was put at another table and I was sitting at a table right next to the rostrum. When the Prime Minister made his speech to that convention, he shuffled the pages and did not read out the nasty bits. That is because he was not prepared to confront the delegates to the convention with the truth. Instead, he said: 'No, I will give you a nice little speech. I will leave out the nasty bits and then go away'.

SPEECH.PARA: There can be no doubt at all that this shameless Government which has been so proud to claim such great credit for the first home owners scheme has, in fact, been planning all the time to cut the infant's throat. The first home owners scheme cuts, taken in conjunction with the recent increases in home loan interest rates-remember the promises of Mr Hawke, Mr Keating and Mr Hurford right throughout last year that interest rates would drop in 1985; as we all know, they have gone up-together with the definite proposal for a 46c in the dollar capital gains tax, will savagely affect morale in the housing industry and will deter prospective first home purchasers. The Government's own expert advisers have already told it that home commencements have peaked-they have, in fact, flattened out-and they will drop by the end of 1985 and continue to drop in 1986. In the light of that information, this disgraceful decision today will inevitably hasten that drop and will lead to a significant loss of employment in the housing and building industries. Mark my words, the Government has done it and has done it deliberately. I suggest its chickens will come home to roost on this matter before this year is ended.

The Government knew before the last Federal election that nearly 75 per cent of the entire first home owners scheme appropriation for 1984-85 had already been committed. Deceitfully it kept this information from the people of Australia before the election. Immediately after the election, what did it do? The Minister personally approved a scheme devised within the Department of Housing and Construction to employ delaying tactics to fob off anxious applicants for first home owner grants. If honourable members do not believe me, the proof of the pudding is in a memorandum which I now present in the chamber from none other than Mr R. J. Egan, the First Assistant Secretary, Housing Policy Division, dated 18 December 1984 to Mr J. Wisken, the Director of the Department of Housing and Construction for the Victoria-Tasmania region. Listen to this deception in the light of what the Government has now done. The memorandum says:
Current expenditure trends indicate the potential to exceed budget allocation unless measures to contain expenditure are introduced forthwith.
The Minister has been advised of measures proposed to contain expenditure and has agreed that the measures be introduced and that their effect be carefully monitored.
What was one of the proposals put forward? In respect of certain cases, the memorandum says:
. . . you might be able to reduce the number of complaints by acknowledging receipt of these applications and advising of delays. The following form of words may be appropriate.
This is a wicked deception to fob off decent young Australians who have made application under this scheme. Listen to these words:

This letter is to acknowledge receipt of your application for first home owners assistance and to advise that in cases such as yours, where funds are not required for settlement, applications are being processed in order of date of receipt. The delay in processing of applications is currently . . . weeks.

The blank space is just to be filled in. That was to stop the young men and women of Australia coming to the counter and finding out what on earth had gone wrong with their applications. When the Minister was pressed on this he not only declined to respond on national radio, when given the opportunity, but just a few weeks later, without any ministerial announcement, suddenly $25m was injected into the scheme. Would not honourable members have thought that that would have been something of which the Government would have been proud, that there would have been a proper ministerial announcement? No, it was just said that a spokesperson in the Minister's office-a spokesperson we note-confirmed that $25m had been injected into the fund. That was welcomed by the industry and by the first home owners. Last month the Government put in $25m but it will take out $40.37m next financial year.

If that is not the greatest con act that I have seen in 18 years in politics, I do not know what is. It is the young people, the poor people-the homeless of Australia-who will suffer due to the Government's decision. The Minister takes some pride in being the first Minister to come into this House and say publicly: 'I put my head on the block. I was the first to go. I am going to be responsible'. The Minister gets 10 out of 10 for economic theory but zero out of 10 for the callous and heartless deceit of the young people of Australia.

Since the Minister's appointment he has gone around the country saying that the first home owners scheme is the greatest thing since sliced bread and, funnily enough, we on this side happen to agree with him in principle. But now, having got maximum prestige, maximum public relations and maximum publicity out of it, having conned the votes of the young people of Australia in December last year, 16 weeks later, one of the Government's most solemn election pledges lies in shreds. The Minister should resign. How on earth can he look at himself in the mirror each morning knowing what he has done? He is the one who came into the House a few minutes ago and said: 'The changes are not very many'. He was the first to capitulate. He should have put his ministry on the line on this matter. He should have fought for it. But of course, as I said last December, on the Minister's track record on immigration, along with that of the Prime Minister, what else could we expect? Within 16 weeks the Minister has already proved that he will make a bigger mess of housing and construction than he did of immigration and ethnic affairs.

I know that there are honourable members on this side of the House who are genuinely concerned about the homeless of Australia, members of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia who are prepared to fight for the right of young Australians to own their own homes. The home ownership rate in Australia has dropped since the Government came to power. There are fewer people owning their own homes in Australia today than there were when Mr Hawke became Prime Minister. This is without doubt the first major scandal of the second Hawke socialist Government. It will cost it dearly at the next Federal election because it has broken a solemn promise. It has betrayed thousands and thousands of decent Australian prospective first home owners. To put it bluntly, the best thing the Minister can do for this country and this Government is to resign forthwith.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

Bill presented by Mr West, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

As I foreshadowed earlier, we propose a number of machinery amendments to the First Home Owners Act 1983. As I informed the Parliament, the first home owners scheme has been the most successful housing assistance scheme this country has ever known. Already it has helped some 142,000 people into homes of their own. Its effect on the housing industry has been marked. As I said earlier, 55,000 new jobs have been created in the industry. Dwelling commencements are predicted to be around 147,000 this financial year, an increase of nearly 40 per cent since this Government came to office. The scheme has now been in operation for some 18 months. During that time a number of shortcomings in the legislation, mainly of a minor nature, have become apparent. The purpose of this Bill is to provide for amendments which overcome these shortcomings.

As I have previously announced, the Government will appropriate $290m to the first home owners scheme for 1985-86. This will enable us to assist a further 82,500 applicants into home ownership. In accordance with the Government's resolve to maintain proper controls over expenditure, one of the amendments included in this Bill will ensure that the first home owners scheme expenditure remains within the Budget appropriation. To achieve this, clause 10 of the Bill amends section 34 of the Act to provide for an annual appropriation and appropriates funds for the balance of this financial year. Clause 6 amends section 16 to make it possible to administer the scheme in accordance with the appropriation made by Parliament.

I find it very strange indeed how some honourable members of this House, and perhaps some industry organisations, can continue to argue for large reductions in the deficit in monetary terms in the next Budget and then oppose some of the individual measures that we intend to put before this House. Let me repeat that in the last Budget we allocated $265m to the first home owners scheme. We estimated that 80,000 approvals would be made and we subsequently found, despite what the spokesman for the Opposition says, that we would need to appropriate some extra money this year. We did so and we will still spend $290m on this scheme this year and help 87,000 people. Next year we intend to help more people-that is, 82,500-than we originally intended to help in 1984-85, at a cost of $290m, which is $25m more than we expected to spend in the 1984-85 Budget. Yet for this we are being lambasted, for the honourable and responsible wish and design to reduce the budgetary deficit, as we are constantly being exhorted to do by honourable members opposite, and we are being harassed because we are taking these measures. I know the Opposition has to take some very hard decisions and decide whether to applaud us for reducing the deficit or attack us on alleged social grounds for making these changes. What has in fact occurred is that the Opposition is absolutely hoisted on its own petard of irresponsibility, whereas we are taking a responsible decision. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), sits there and says nothing because he knows I am right. If we are going to save a bit of money and reduce the deficit, obviously we have to take some decisions and announce them now to get the full year effect, and that is exactly what we have done. In case the Opposition has missed the message, I repeat that by the end of 1985-86 225,000 households will have been assisted by our scheme and they will have been paid fairly promptly in contrast to the nine months it took to pay people their benefits under the Opposition's scheme. They are the facts of the matter.

There are other clauses in this Bill which are machinery clauses. I will not deal with them in great detail, but honourable members can read the explanatory notes. They are clauses that would otherwise have been included in a miscellaneous amendments Bill, if we had not been bringing down this legislation, that is, in regard to the changes in the standing appropriation to the annual appropriation. Clauses 4 and 5 of the Bill will amend the Act to close loopholes identified by a recent decision of the Federal Court of Australia. The decision has raised the possibility that, contrary to the intention of the Government when it introduced the first home owners scheme, an applicant or applicants acquiring only a small interest in a dwelling could qualify for the maximum benefit. The clauses also make similar provision in relation to applicants who have shares in a body corporate for amounts less than the value of the dwelling.

The remaining amendments are of a minor machinery nature, as I said, and are explained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable members. In summary they are as follows: Clauses 5 (d) and 8 (b) correct the anomalies relating to previous home ownership and year of income for migrants. The amendment to clause 5 (d) makes it clear that my Department may disregard previous home ownership in cases in which it is clear that the applicant lived briefly in the residence but for reasons such as break-up of marriage it was not his or her principal place of residence. The amendment in clause 8 is designed to bring the treatment of migrants fully into line with that of other applicants for the purposes of determining their income year; that is, they may be tested on the basis of their current year of income where this is lower than the previous full year of income in Australia.

Clause 5 (e) clarifies the Secretary's discretion to determine the 'prescribed date' of an application. This amendment follows a recent Federal Court judgment and is necessary to give effect to the original intention of the legislation. It will also make sure that applicants who experience a long delay with their contract are not disadvantaged.

Clause 9 amends section 23 to permit applicants who have received assistance in respect of contracts which have fallen through to offset that assistance against a subsequent entitlement rather than to have to repay the earlier benefit, as is now the case. Clause 3 amends the definition of 'rural property' in section 4 to that originally intended. This will ensure that it applies only to genuine farming properties on which the applicant has secure tenure. Clause 7 amends section 21 to enable the Secretary to determine an applicant's taxable income for the purposes of the Act when the applicant is not required to lodge a taxation return. Clause 13 of the Bill provides for the removal of all sexist language from the principal Act. The remaining clauses are of a procedural and evidentiary nature. These amendments, other than the change to funding arrangements and the procedural and evidentiary changes, will apply in relation to applications in respect of which the prescribed date is later than 16 April 1985.

The changed funding arrangements will apply from the date of royal assent but will have the effect of applying controls on aggregate expenditure as from today. The other changes will apply from royal assent. I emphasise that these changes will not affect the overall level of assistance to first home buyers, which, as I have said, will assist some 82,500 households in 1985-86. I commend the Bill to the House.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully showeth that:

(ii) The imposition of post-secondary tuition fees of comparable levels to those imposed prior to 1971 would force many currently enrolled students to discontinue their studies and deter many persons willing and able at present to undertake post-secondary study from doing so.

We electors of South Australia ask that the Federal Government recognise God in our National Anthem by replacing the word 'Advance' in the last line with 'God Bless' reading 'God Bless Australia Fair.' in the last line of each verse because-
(1) seeing the words of Advance Australia Fair are being changed for our National Anthem, it would be desirable to include recognition of God;
(2) a recent survey showed that 89% of Australian people believe there is a God. This is a large majority;
(3) if we ask God to bless us, He will; and
(4) God has promised, if people turn from evil to Him, He will reward them.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will urge the Government to make this alteration and recognise God in our National Anthem.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to protect the rights and interests of Australian citizens who live in Queensland against the ACTU planned blockade of that State.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —As things stand now, from midnight this Thursday the State of Queensland and its population of about 2.5 million of our fellow Australians will be subjected to a transport blockade. From midnight this Thursday, road, rail, sea and air services into and out of Queensland will cease, cutting Queensland off from the rest of the country. A visitor to Australia might well ask: 'Are you at war? Has some foreign expeditionary force suddenly landed on your shores? Are enemy troops now quickly seeking to sever transport links between Queensland and the rest of the Commonwealth?'

SPEECH.PARA: If this were the case, if we were at war, would not the Federal Government be making great haste? Would it not be pulling out all the stops to protect our fellow Australians who happen to be living in Queensland? Of course we are not at war and we are not subject to a foreign military threat, but the point is that the immediate consequences for people living in Queensland will be largely the same. Equally immediate is the need for the Federal Government to move to protect these people, to preserve their rights and uphold their freedoms under the Australian Constitution-the freedoms of interstate travel, trade and commerce.

The planned Australian Council of Trade Unions sponsored transport blockade of Queensland, this assault on the freedom of our fellow Australians living in Queensland, is nothing short of outrageous. It deserves the strongest condemnation-from Perth to Sydney and from Hobart to Darwin, the length and breadth of this nation. It demands immediate action by the Federal Government. It is a national crisis, as mentioned by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) during Question Time, but what is the Government doing about it? It is doing nothing. The New South Wales branch of the Transport Workers Union has already broken ranks and jumped the gun. It is applying bans from tonight. Mr Harry Quinn, the Secretary of the New South Wales branch of the Transport Workers Union, believes the blockade should be longer than the 24 hours advocated by the ACTU. That is why his branch is starting already. He advocates that it should go not for 24 hours but for a month. My only advice to all those visitors to Canberra from Queensland is that they get back before Friday.

This Government is doing nothing to protect Queenslanders and doing nothing to protect other Australians who want to travel to Queensland or trade with their fellow citizens in that State. This Government is doing nothing to discourage unions from wanting to take what even the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) has described as regressive action. Are we to be treated to the spectacle of Transport Workers Union thugs picketing the highways and byways into and out of Queensland before this Government is forced to act?

While the Government is generally responsible for this failure to act, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations is especially responsible and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is particularly responsible. It is the Prime Minister who keeps telling us about the Government's so-called special relationship with the trade unions. If this blockade is an example of that special relationship with the trade unions, God help all of us. The Prime Minister and his Government, by their inaction, are giving vindictive and irresponsible unions their head, allowing the actions of democratically elected governments to be challenged by union leaders representing no one but their own sectional interests. Is this a government for the people or for the unions? This Government's inaction and its unwillingness to go in to bat for the people of Queensland and for all of us against union thuggery tell us who this Government is for. Australia now has a government of the unions, for the unions, by the unions.

Just look at this Government. The Prime Minister is the biggest ex-union boss of them all and his sidekick, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, is the present ACTU man in Canberra. Together they make a good team-good for the unions, but bad for the wider Australian community. This Government is being more than soft on these unions. It is supporting their actions. By doing nothing the Government is supporting the blockade. By appealing to International Labour Organisation conventions the Prime Minister is undermining a democratically elected government's strong and publicly supported stand. Who suffers? It is the people of Queensland and all Australians. Does the Government see its duty as protecting only the interests of Australians in other States? One might well ask: Does the Prime Minister have it in particularly for Queensland, or would he dump any State if his union mates decided to have a go and bung on a blockade of Western Australia, Tasmania or South Australia?

It is not just the Opposition which has these grave suspicions about on whose behalf the Government governs. Indeed, one need only look at the money market to see that the business community has the same doubts about this Government's authority and impartiality. The fall of the Australian dollar is a clear indication that the financial community believes that this Government has lost its authority and its control. There could not be a clearer example than this. From the outside it looks like the ACTU calls the shots and the Prime Minister and his Government do their job-the ACTU way. The Queensland dispute proves that that is the way things work in Canberra under this compromised government. For the duration of this Government it has been attempting to keep at arm's length its dependent and supplicant relationship with the trade union movement. We have heard much about the special relationship the Government has with the trade union movement and about the industrial peace and harmony that that special relationship brings to bear. But we can see how this relationship is now working in reverse, as this Government does the bidding of its union masters.

Let us look at what the Government could be doing to protect Queenslanders from this outrageous union action. Right now we could be debating in this chamber appropriate legislation, and the Senate could be debating such legislation not long after. We could be debating use of the Trade Practices Act to restrain Transport Workers Union members from conducting the blockade. We could now be passing the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Bill and bringing that legislation to bear on Federal Government employees who are going to go along with this blockade. We could be passing that legislation in this chamber right now and sending a message to the other place so that the Government could have on hand this evening some legislative action to meet this blockade on Friday. The Government, in the light of its special relationship, could be taking political action-supposedly the Government's strong suit. The Government could be using honeyed words. It could be having a cup of tea with or buying a beer for its union mates; a chat here and a deal there-the special relationship. It is a special relationship indeed! I say it is one that puts union interests ahead of public interest. It is a special relationship that supports the guerrilla action of non-representative organisations without popularly elected leaders instead of supporting the action of a democratically elected government, in this case in Queensland, trying to protect its own citizens.

Let us have a look at the Transport Workers Union, which has broken ranks and is at the forefront of this present dispute. The Prime Minister, the Minister for Industrial Relations and other members of the Government should have absolutely no compunction in taking the strongest possible action against the Transport Workers Union. Their failure to do so makes a mockery of their commitment to responsible unions in this country. The TWU has been one of the unions that has consistently refused to accept the spirit of the accord that the Prime Minister and his Minister are always talking about. Look at the record of the TWU in the period since this Government came to office. Forget about the wildcat strikes, the airline strikes, the bans it imposed on State and Federal governments and the Victorian milk strike of l98l. Forget about even the scandal of the bullying of small business people in Sydney, in the case of Laidlaw, and forget about the case in Western Australia when the union stood over the Western Australian Government to force it to drop extortion charges against the union secretary, John O'Connor. Just look at the record of the Transport Workers Union under this Government. It fuelled destructive demarcation disputes in the Kimberleys and refused to accept a Western Australian Industrial Commission decision, not once, not twice, but three times, until it got its way. It threatened to ban the handling of medical materials, thereby putting hundreds of medical patients at risk, and threatened to bring the New South Wales transport industry to a complete halt unless employers agreed within a week to superannuation schemes. That demand was completly outside the spirit of the accord and in defiance of the ACTU. There was also the Australa-wide airline stoppage of 23 May. This is the union that is at the vanguard of this industrial blockade of Queensland.

There has been a range of threats by the Transport Workers Union to this Government about taking strike action if this Government does not change its tax policies. This is the union that the Government will not stand up to. It is a union which has flouted its authority at every step, a union which behaves very much like those Queensland power unions whose irresponsible attitude forced the Queensland Government into having to move to protect its own citizens. It is a union whose leader in New South Wales has said: 'If we are to be concerned about elections or politicians we would never get anything done for our own members'. That is the contempt for democracy which the Transport Workers Union has shown on many instances in the past and which it is now displaying in respect of this blockade. The Prime Minister and his Government are failing to live up to their responsibilities. This Government is not acting without fear or favour in the interests of the community at large. It is caving in to its union bosses and its union mates. It is abandoning Queenslanders and allowing Queensland to be stood over by a clutch of union heavies. The Prime Minister wanted his job and the Minister wanted his job and they both have them. They both take the money. It is about time they started earning it. The Prime Minister and his Minister have not yet cast off their role of union go-betweens acting in union interests to achieve union ends. That is not the behaviour that this nation needs of a Prime Minister and a Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. The Prime Minister, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and all the other Ministers have higher duties to protect the public interest and not sectional interests, to defend responsible action and not belligerent blockading by Transport Workers Union thugs. If the Prime Minister and his Ministers cannot do the job they should give someone a go who can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just listened to the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) speak for about l3.5 minutes in which time he said not one word of criticism of the Queensland Government. He spent all his time demonstrating his well-known paranoia about the trade union movement. Far be it from me to say that the trade union movement is perfect in every way. Obviously it does things which this Government does not support. As I have indicated in Question Time, taking industrial action in relation to this matter is one of those things. Nevertheless, I think it is interesting to note that the honourable member for Tangney said not one word of criticism of the Queensland Government in the whole of his time.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to put it on the record that it is now quite clear that the Opposition totally, unambiguously, without any qualification, supports the Queensland Government. In doing so it is supporting action which I think previous Liberal governments would not have supported and disparaging international treaties which I think previous Liberal governments have shown an inclination to support. I think it is deplorable that this Opposition has now shown that it will go as low as possible in order to support its paranoia about the trade union movement and to grasp opportunistically at any straw which it thinks will get it some kind of electoral support. That is what this pathetic display today was all about.

Let me say at the outset that the Government totally refutes the basis of this matter of public importance, the basis being that the Government is doing nothing about the planned blockade of Queensland. This Government has tried to use its best endeavours, in a situation in which it has no substantial powers to legislate to take action in that regard, to say to the Queensland Government: 'The approach that you are on is the wrong approach to good industrial relations in this country. If you will only have a meeting with the trade union movement to discuss what might be done in relation to the electricity industry, we may be able to find a basis for the amicable settlement of this whole mess'. The Queensland Government has refused to accept any such discussions, indicating thereby that it is determined to bring about a total confrontation. I do not know what its motives are in doing so. One can speculate about that but I do not wish to take up the time of the House in doing that. Whatever those motives are, it is quite clear that the Queensland Government is not interested in preventing total industrial confrontation in this country. It is interested in creating that confrontation. When the electricity dispute was before the State Industrial Commission the Queensland Government twice refused to accept recommendations from the State Industrial Commission which would have settled the dispute. The unions agreed to accept those recommendations but the Queensland Government said: 'No'. There was no basis of settlement because the Queensland Government would not accept the State Industrial Commission's recommendations. Not only did it not accept them but also it denigrated the State Industrial Commission, making quite disparaging remarks about that Commission, which led to the State Industrial Commission calling a special meeting of that Commission to reject the statements made by the Premier.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is all history. What are you going to do now?

—It is not history of which the honourable member seems to be aware. The President of the Commission made the point that the statements made by the Premier had been quite absurd. I think it is obvious, therefore, that the Queensland Government, from its actions, does not want to settle the dispute. If it wants to have total confrontation, it is in a position to bring that confrontation about. That is what is happening, very regrettably.

SPEECH.PARA: We totally repudiate the suggestions from the Opposition that we could settle this dispute by rushing in with draconian legislation of one sort or another. That kind of legislation would not settle this dispute. It would not stop the blockade. It would exacerbate and inflame the situation and we would rush to a much wider confrontation much more quickly. That is the kind of situation that would develop if we adopted the approach that the Opposition would like us to adopt. We will not adopt that approach. We have put a constructive proposal to the Queensland Government and, unfortunately, it has been rejected. If discussions had been held, I believe that the union movement would have been in a position to put some constructive proposals to the Queensland Government which would have improved the industrial relations situation in that industry, and in a way which I think the Queensland Government would not find unacceptable. Apparently that is not what it is interested in talking about. It just wants to have a situation in which there is massive confrontation.

One must ask: What are its motives? What is the Queensland Government really trying to achieve? Is it trying to get some sort of strategic breakthrough against the power of the trade union movement? Maybe that is its motive. Maybe it is wider than that. Maybe it is concerned that it should be doing something to cover the fact that the Queensland economy, relatively speaking, is by far the worst in this country. Maybe it is so concerned about that fact that it wants to distract the attention of the Queensland people from the fact that this State is being hopelessly managed. In the last l2 months it had a growth in employment of only 0.3 per cent when the nation as a whole had a growth of 2 per cent. Its rate of unemployment has risen by 7.3 per cent in the last l2 months compared with a national decline of 4.l per cent. New motor vehicle registrations in Queensland in the three months to the end of February l985 fell by 0.5 per cent compared with a l2 per cent rise nationally. Building approvals rose by only l.7 per cent in the three months to the end of January l985, whereas a year earlier there was a 9.5 per cent increase for Australia as a whole. The value of other building approvals rose by 36 per cent in Queensland in that period compared with 67.4 per cent in Australia. Private investment for the September quarter l984 fell by 20.6 per cent over the September quarter l983 in Queensland whereas in Australia as a whole it rose by 2.3 per cent. Bankruptcies increased by 26.4 per cent in Queensland in l984 against 1983--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. My point of order, which is a substantive one, is that the remarks by the Minister are simply not relevant to the matter of public importance.
—Order! I have listened very carefully to the Minister. The remarks are well in context with the discussion that is before the House. I call the Minister.

—As I was saying, in Queensland in l984 there was an increase of 26.4 per cent in bankruptcies, whereas they fell by 8.2 per cent in Australia as a whole. In respect of industrial disputes, for the l2 months to January l985, there was a decline of l5.6 per cent for Australia in the days lost through industrial disputes, but in Queensland they increased by 84 per cent. It is quite obvious that the Queensland Government, at least in part, is trying very hard to distract the attention of the Queensland people from the enormous shambles that it made of the economy of that State and that, relative to the rest of Australia, it is performing abysmally. Perhaps that is the major motivation in what it is about.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say that in pursuit of these objectives, whatever they are, it is quite clear that the Queensland Government is prepared to make unprecedented attacks on the democratic rights and the civil liberties of the Queensland citizens. We have heard not one word from the honourable member for Tangney about that. He does not have one iota of concern about the fact that civil liberties are being attacked in that State. We have had all sorts of disinterested people, such as churchmen and others, saying that they are greatly concerned about what is happening to civil liberties in that State, but we have not heard one word from the Opposition of any concern about that whatever. If action is taken against unions it does not matter; democratic rights and civil rights can be chucked out the window. They are only unionists after all, and, therefore, second-grade citizens in the view of members of the Opposition. They have that kind of approach. We can expect the kinds of things we have heard from the honourable member for Tangney. We can expect members of the Opposition to say, as he said, that the International Labour Organisation does not matter. He said: 'What does it matter if you breach ILO conventions? Who cares about them? They are only ILO conventions'. To quote him directly, he said: 'They are irrelevant to the Queensland industrial situation. It is pointless for the Prime Minister to invoke them. Most of Australia has never heard of the ILO and would not regard the proclamations of a far off international organisation as relevant to Australian industrial relations'. What an amazing and deplorable statement that was.

I think it is regrettable in the extreme that members of the Opposition are now expressing a total lack of concern for the ILO which, after all, is the labour arm of the United Nations. Presumably those comments go also for the international covenants which have been breached by the Queensland Government and presumably, therefore, it does not care much about the United Nations either. I think it is regrettable and deplorable that members of the Opposition have now seen fit to disparage the ILO in particular and say that that does not matter a damn because that has never been the position of the Opposition before, as I understand it. Indeed, previous Ministers and shadow Ministers have gone to the ILO and expressed their great support for it. I think that the honourable member for Tangney, in taking the stand that he has, has taken the members of the Opposition to depths to which they have never plunged.

It is a fact that there has been a breach of several ILO conventions, such as ILO Convention 29, ILO Convention l05-both of which relate to forced labour-the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, ILO Convention 87 concerning freedom of association and protection of the right to organise, the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights and the ILO Convention concerning the application of the principles of the right to organise and to bargain collectively. All of those covenants have been breached by the Queensland legislation and the Opposition does not give a damn. I think that is deplorable. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an attachment to a letter to the Premier which sets out all of the breaches by Queensland industrial legislation of international treaties to which Australia is a party. I want to give the Opposition the opportunity to have a look at it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Is leave granted?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, it is not a written statement and we could not agree to it.
—Members of the Opposition obviously want to hide the evidence.
—That is the rule of the House.
—There it is. Have a look at it.
—Order! Leave is not granted.

—I note the fact that the Opposition seeks to hide from the Australian people the facts of the breaches of ILO conventions and international covenants. Mr Deputy Speaker, let me say also-time does not permit me to go into the details-that in the actions taken by the Queensland Government there have been many other breaches of democratic rights and civil liberties which are not breaches specifically of any international treaties but which are certainly deplorable developments. The picketing one is one obvious such development. I do not need to elaborate on that, but I do need to elaborate just slightly on the conditions for re-employment of electricity workers. Some 900 are still without a job. Those people have been told they can get their jobs back if they rat on their mates. They have to tell the authorities whether they were forced out on strike and who forced them; what evidence there is of harassment and by whom; they have to name the people who caused any harassment; name any pickets and name any workmates who have urged them to remain on strike. They also have to agree to sign a no-strike clause for a 38-hour week as against the 36 1/3-hour week they had before and agree to other various detrimental conditions of employment compared with what they previously had.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have seen in Queensland has been the use by the Queensland Government of its legislative powers to override the conditions of employment established by the State Industrial Commission. The criticism of the State Industrial Commission has been taken to a point where the authority of the Commission was taken away in this area and a new tribunal established. This tribunal does not have the full authority of the previous State Industrial Commission and is unable to deal with disciplinary measures taken against employees for breach of their conditions of employment.

Time does not permit me to go into more detail in that regard. But we do deplore the great array of undemocratic actions taken by the Queensland Government. Let me say that the actions taken by this Government are, quite clearly, counter-productive. The way to achieve industrial peace is not by seeking to enforce it in this manner. Many previous attempts have been made, including by the Fraser Government, quite unsuccessfully. This is not the way to resolve the difficult situation in that State. The way we are going to get better industrial relations in this country is by the methods used by this Government. It has achieved a dramatic reduction in the level of industrial disputes. In the last l2 months, l,326,000 days have been lost compared with 4.5 million in the last year of the Fraser Government. There has been an enormous reduction in the level of industrial disputes-the lowest level for l7 years. It is quite obvious that this Government knows how to achieve industrial peace. The Queensland Government is not interested in doing anything about it.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, it is obvious--

—Order! I have not called the honourable member for Dawson yet. I will not call the honourable member for Dawson until there is some order from honourable members sitting behind him on the front bench. That order was not apparent during the remarks of the Minister even though I asked for it on numerous occasions. I call the honourable member for Dawson.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I speak to the matter of public importance wondering whether the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) has read the wording of it and wondering whether he realises the importance of the debate that is taking place and in which he has participated. I regard this as a watershed decision: The Government either tells the union bosses what they should be doing or it continues to be led down the road by the nose as it has been over the last two years. This matter of public importance is about who governs-the Government or people who have union positions, who flout their power and who believe that they can govern in that right and that right alone. It is a matter of whether the Australian Council of Trade Unions, an unelected group, is going to tell the Government and continue to tell the Government what it is going to do. It is ridiculous for the Minister to say that he wants to incorporate a paper when he knows, or he should know, that it is a precedent of the House that that is not allowed. I believe he knows as little about his own portfolio as he does about the forms of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister mentioned that the Government has no power, that it is not going to introduce draconian legislation to try to put a stop to this matter. He wants to talk to the Queensland Government, but he mentions nothing about talking to the ACTU and nothing about talking to Simon Crean. Through questioning this afternoon it is obvious that he knows that the Trade Practices Act could put a stop to this immediately either through section 45, or through power vested in the Minister under section 80 to impose an injunction on the unions. But what does he do? He backs down and brings on a tirade against the Queensland Government just to indicate that the Queensland Government and the State of Queensland are in the black book of the Commonwealth just as the Tasmanian Government was when it first came to office.

It is not good enough for Government members to come into this House and cry the old story of the Queensland Government's inability to do this, that or the other. All the Queensland Government is trying to do in this case is to govern for its people, as is its elected right, and not be forced into a situation through the mistakes of the Electrical Trades Union which caused this dispute. I suggest that, if a secret poll of members of the ACTU were carried out, asking what they thought of the actions of the ETU in this situation, the ETU would get only one vote; that is, its own vote. It is said that the Queensland Government should go to arbitration and should hold discussions. But on no fewer than five occasions the ETU was instructed and was demanded to go back to work. What did it do? It flouted the orders every time. The three times mentioned by the Minister that the Queensland Government took no notice were following recommendations, not demands, as the Commission realised that it could not make the demands as was suggested. It is the height of hypocrisy for Government members to come in here and suggest that the Queensland Government is creating this situation. All it wanted initially was to have the right to employ private labour. All it wanted was the right to employ private contractors.

It is interesting to note that the whole demand of the union movement is to fill those thousand jobs. I tell the Minister, in case he has not been over the border lately, that those thousand jobs are filled. The work is going on productively. The only thing that is going on south of the border is a deliberate misrepresentation of the facts. I will instance one particular occasion where apparently the ETU in Victoria issued a Press statement stating that three electricity linesmen have been killed in Queensland since the strike was broken. That is absolute rot; it is the type of fear that is being put into people south of the border. There is talk of draconian legislation by the Commonwealth being required. It is not required. I suggest that even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) does not agree that the legislation presently in force in Queensland is draconian. The Minister invoked the Archbishop of Canterbury, on the basis that after a couple of days visit to Queensland he knew all about the situation. What he did was to read the rubbish put out by the Labor Government here.

All that has happened under the two pieces of legislation is to ensure that the people employed by the Electricity Commission are not harassed. The Federal Government brought in legislation last year to ensure that women are not harassed, but it is not prepared to ensure that people lawfully employed and lawfully contracted are not harassed as they go through strike gates. It is a reflection on the Government that one of its senators is under the threat of imprisonment but was let out for Easter. Another, Senator Childs, had the wisdom to walk away from the confrontation and go into the backyard because he knew that where there is a law there has to be order.

This Government and the ACTU are trying to promote a heap of lies in the south which are meant to blanket the inefficiencies and the stupidity of the ETU in going to the wall on this occasion. It went to the wall and it will stay there because of its own stupidity. The stupidity of the ACTU is shown in its wanting to back this to the hilt.

Let me say that it is not the union people we are bashing; it is the union leaders. I will give a couple of examples to take us away from the ETU. I understand that on Sunday night there was a flight from Brisbane to Sydney and on to Canberra. As there was a sick hostess who could not take her place on that flight from Sydney to Canberra, the union leader would not allow a substitute. What happened? The plane had to be downgraded from a Boeing 727 to a DC9. Fifty people had to stay overnight in Sydney and the others arrived here two and a half hours late. There are members on the Government side who will verify that fact and who would complain as bitterly as we do about the actions, not of the union members but of the union leader.

I will give another example of the great freedom and democratic principles that exist within the union movement! I know of a situation where an employer had to choose between two members of a union. The employer chose one but the union leader would not accept the one chosen by the employer; he wants to impose in that work force someone of lesser efficiency and lesser quality. That is what we are complaining about. That is what the Queensland Government is complaining about. It wants the rights of people recognised so that they can go about their lawful business, do their work and be productive so that the economy which is often talked about, not only for Queensland but for Australia, will improve. It is the little csars within the union movement, who are not elected to government in Queensland, any other State or the Commonwealth, who are imposing their will on Australia and the States. This is the first time ever that a government has had the will, the desire or the real impetus to put something in place, not for itself but for the people of Queensland. If a secret ballot were held on this matter at the moment in Queensland or indeed throughout Australia, I believe that the response would indicate that Australians-the workers, the small business people, the housewives and the aged-believe that enough is enough and that it is time that not only this Government in Canberra but also all State governments adhered to the principles.

The Government has been led down the road. I just wonder whether this is another indication that it will be led further down the road. We had the Commonwealth employees employment provision legislation revoked. The prices and incomes accord was agreed to because it was the will of the ACTU. If we ask the sugar industry, the coal industry or any of the other industries that are going down the tube in the Australian economy at the moment what say they had in the prices and income accord, we will find that they had absolutely none. All of the things that were in the prices and income accord, and those outside the prices and income accord, have the approbation of this Government and it does not have the guts to do anything about them. The Government knows who its masters are. Its masters are the ACTU members.
