TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

First, this Bill introduces a range of significant amendments to the Bankruptcy Act 1966. One group of amendments is consequent upon a review of the operation of the Act. This review, of a detailed and technical nature, commenced under the previous Government and has been completed by this Government. Secondly, the Bill contains a number of amendments flowing from the Government's policy decision to modify the legislative implementation of the Review of Commonwealth Functions decision in this area. A detailed description of the provisions of the Bill appears in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated to honourable members.
Review of the Bankruptcy Act 1966

In the past two decades a number of countries which have insolvency legislation of similar derivation to our own Bankruptcy Act have embarked upon a review of their legislation. In Australia there have been two major reports: The report of the Clyne Committee appointed by the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth to Review the Bankruptcy Law of the Commonwealth in 1962 which led to the passage of the Bankruptcy Act, and the sixth report of the Law Reform Commission entitled 'Insolvency: The Regular Payment of Debts'. The Government has approved the preparation of draft legislation, along the lines of that recommended by the Law Reform Commission, for exposure for public comment. The Law Reform Commission currently is working on a reference to report generally on insolvency law and practice, as part of a thorough review of the area. Other countries have carried out similar, in-depth reviews-England in 1981, the Republic of Ireland in 1972 and New Zealand, Scotland, Canada and Ghana in the last two decades. The amendments proposed in the Bill presently before the House are intended to address some of the problem areas in this field pending the report of the Law Reform Commission.
Removal of Anomalies

The Bankruptcy Amendment Act 1980 created the Common Investment Fund which, essentially, comprises the proceeds of the realisation of assets by the Official Trustee in Bankruptcy. Experience has revealed some shortcomings in two of the sections of the Act dealing with the Fund, namely section 20B and section 20H. Amendments to these sections are proposed by clauses 11 and 12 respectively of the Bill before honourable members. Similarly, time and judicial decisions have exposed flaws in other provisions of the Act. Thus, clause 25 proposes an amendment to section 125 of the Act to ensure that the control which can be exercised by the trustee over bank accounts of an undischarged bankrupt can also be exercised over accounts with financial institutions other than banks. Clause 20 of the Bill proposes an amendment to section 64, 'First meeting of creditors', which will defer the need for a first meeting until after a statement of affairs has been filed. In most cases it is futile to convene a meeting before a statement of affairs has been filed as the statement details the creditors of the bankrupt and the moneys owed to them.
Enhancement of the Special Protection Accorded to Maintenance Creditors

In 1980 the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act in its report entitled 'Family Law in Australia: A Report of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act', made a specific recommendation, at paragraph 5-83, relating to changes to the Bankruptcy Act to facilitate the enforcement of maintenance orders. This recommendation is the genesis of the amendment to section 40 (3) which is proposed by clause 13 of the Bill. A further amendment, relating to maintenance is proposed by clause 3 to remove any doubt that the term 'maintenance order' includes an order for arrears of maintenance. It is realised that the problem of enforcement of maintenance orders is an enormous one in our community. Further action in this area will require some time. However the changes proposed in this Bill will alleviate in part the difficulties confronting a maintenance creditor endeavouring to recover arrears of maintenance.
Improving the Administration of the Act

As the Bankruptcy Act presently stands, appointments to statutory offices are made by the Governor-General under section 16 of the Act. It is considered more suitable that such appointments should be made by the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department, which is responsible for the administration of this division of the Act. Another change in this category involves the functions and powers of the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy. For example, clause 4 proposes to amend section 12 of the Act to enable the Inspector-General to obtain from registered trustees such reports as he may presently obtain from registrars and official receivers. It is also proposed by clause 32, to amend section 179 to permit the Inspector-General to make application to the Federal Court of Bankruptcy for an inquiry into the conduct of a trustee. At present, in the event that inquiries or investigations disclose some irregularity, the Inspector-General has no power to act upon his findings. The amendment proposed to section 179 will rectify this shortcoming.
Achieving Greater Uniformity with Companies Act 1982

Although there are some significant differences in the role of the Bankruptcy Act and that of the winding up provisions of the Companies Act, to the extent that both enactments deal with insolvency it is desirable that creditors should receive similar treatment irrespective of whether the debtor is an individual or a corporate body. Consequently clauses 23 and 24 propose quite significant amendments to those sections of the Act which regulate the rights of the creditors inter se to achieve a greater degree of uniformity with the corresponding provisions of the Companies Act. Very significant changes are proposed by clauses 29 to 32 of the Bill to Part VIII of the Act, which relates to trustees. The amendments will entrench in the Act the qualifications which are necessary for a person to obtain registration as a trustee. They will also permit a greater degree of supervision of the continuing suitability for registration of trustees. There is at present no requirement for regular reporting by trustees or for the updating of bonds by registered trustees in bankruptcy. Once again many of these changes are modelled upon the corresponding provisions of the Companies Act relating to the registration of liquidators.
Modifications of the Review of Commonwealth Functions Decision

In 1981 the previous Government amended the Bankruptcy Act in order to channel a large proportion of the administration of bankrupt estates to the private sector. Most of those changes, which were implemented by the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Act 1981, are modified by this Bill. Experience has shown that the changes were implemented in such haste that no thought was given to the need for new measures to ensure that the newly expanded role of private trustees was subjected to proper scrutiny and regulation. The number of new estates handled by private trustees grew from 13 out of 5,154 in 1980-81, or 0.25 per cent, to 1,063 out of 5,156 in 1982-83, in other words it escalated to 20.62 per cent.

It is not the policy of the Government to exclude registered trustees from the administration of bankrupt estates. However it is apparent that the majority of registered trustees perceive their role as administrators, and not as investigators. Thus the registered trustees have realised assets and distributed dividends, but have largely disregarded the discretionary duty to investigate and report upon the conduct, dealings and affairs of the bankrupt.

Investigation of bankruptcies must continue to be given significant priority. Insolvency fraud does occur, even if only in a small number of bankruptcies. Mr Costigan's Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union uncovered some instances of persons using bankruptcy to defraud their creditors whilst concealing the gains for their own benefit. Consequently clause 10 proposes an amendment to section 19 of the Act so that in a bankruptcy administered by a registered trustee, the Official Receiver will have a reserve power of investigation. In the first instance the duty to investigate will remain with the registered trustee. If however the trustee indicates that he or she does not intend to investigate, then the Official Receiver may elect to do so.

Honourable members will note that a number of the amendments proposed in this Bill relate to the control over or regulation of registered trustees; for example, clauses 4, 29, 31, 32, to which I have already referred. All these changes have become necessary as a result of inadequacies in the Act exposed during the time of an expanded role for private trustees. The details were outlined in the debate in the Senate. Briefly, some trustees have engaged in distinctly unprofessional conduct. Over the past 12 months the Federal Court of Australia has cancelled the registration of some trustees as a result of misconduct. Some other trustees have themselves become bankrupt as a result of their mishandling of administrations under the Bankruptcy Act. Statistics indicate that many trustees, even most trustees, do not take seriously the investigative and reporting duties which the Act imposes on the trustee of a bankrupt estate. Contrary to the lack of choice as to trustee imposed by the RCF changes, a petitioner, whether petitioning creditor or petitioning debtor, will have an option to file the consent of a registered trustee to act as trustee of the estate. It will also remain possible for the creditors to meet together and pass a resolution appointing a registered trustee as trustee of the estate, pursuant to section 157 of the Act. The reversal of the RCF decision will not, therefore, preclude registered trustees from playing a significant role under the Act. However, it will ensure that the involvement of registered trustees is coupled with proper safeguards and checks.

In summary, therefore, the changes proposed by this Bill represent a blend of the experience before the RCF changes and the experience subsequent to those changes. However, I point out to the House that, in deciding to modify the changes effected by Act No. 74 of 1981, the Government had decided not to reintroduce the earlier prohibition of solicitation, contained in the old section 166, which may have reduced the participation of private registered trustees prior to 1981.
Financial Impact Statement

The Bill will result, in due course, in an increase in the number of new estates administered by the bankruptcy branch of Attorney-General's Department. The increased workload will require some extra resources, estimated at 42 extra staff. The resources required will be reviewed in the 1986-87 Budget context. This demand for extra resources however, will be offset by other savings in expenditure. At present a task force of 47 temporary employees is working in the branch to reduce backlogs in work. The engagement of the estimated 42 staff will permit the branch to administer the level of new estates, and, with the amendments in this Bill, to prevent the recurrence of backlogs. The need for the extra staff will coincide with the conclusion of the task of the task force. Also, the increased costs will be partly offset by expected increased revenue from the Common Investment Fund and from fees.

The salaries and overhead costs associated with the 42 extra staff amount to $1,275,616. The anticipated increase in official fees amounts to $282,528 and the extra revenue from the Common Investment Fund should be of the order of $124,000; a total of $406,528. This creates a net increase in expenditure of $869,088, offset by a reduction of $1,646,384 from the completion of the task force, leading to an overall saving of $777,296 over current levels of expenditure. These figures relate to the expected costs and additional revenue once the changes have become fully operational. There will therefore be no financial impact in the current fiscal year, or the fiscal year 1985-86. The financial impact will be felt only in the first half of the year 1986-87. I commend the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bankruptcy Amendment Bill l985 is a revamped version of the Bill which was introduced into the Senate last year. It will effect changes to five areas of the existing bankruptcy legislation. The Opposition is able to support the vast bulk of the amendments proposed by the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The first major area of the proposed amendments relates to maintenance creditors. The first point to be made is that the amendments contained in the Bill will be made to facilitate the enforcement of maintenance orders. This will help to alleviate a growing problem, recognised in l980 by the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act, which recommended that these changes be made to the Bankruptcy Act. The Opposition is pleased that the Government has now moved to implement that recommendation. Under the amendment, a failure to pay for a period of 12 months maintenance due pursuant to a maintenance order will constitute an act of bankruptcy upon which a creditor's petition can be founded by the maintenance creditor.

Collection of maintenance and the enforcement of maintenance orders are growing problems. Some maintenance debtors have taken it upon themselves to flout the orders of the Family Court, leaving many maintenance creditors in dire financial difficulties. This amendment proposed by the Bill will have a useful facility to induce the recalcitrant maintenance debtor to pay up. It is significant that only the maintenance creditor will be able to found a bankruptcy petition on this particular act of bankruptcy, and the maintenance debtor's general creditors will not be able to use this device. This is a step in the right direction, which the Opposition supports.

The second area is those matters relating to the proposal to implement uniformity with the Companies Act. Amendments to be made to the Bankruptcy Act by this Bill propose the creation of uniformity between the treatment of creditors on the winding up of a company under the Companies Act and creditors upon bankruptcy. The proposed amendments invoke, firstly, changes to the priority of payments in the Bankruptcy Act, bringing them into line with the parallel provisions contained in the Companies Act relating to the order of payment of debts on a winding up. The second proposal in this area deals with the supervision and registration of trustees in bankruptcy. Under this proposal the Bankruptcy Act will specify the qualification necessary for a person to obtain registration, modelled upon the corresponding requirements in the Companies Act relating to liquidators and auditors.

The third amendment in this area proposes the introduction of a system of triennial reporting by registered trustees in bankruptcy, based on parallel terms to the requirement upon liquidators under the Companies Act. These proposals have the support of the Opposition, which is of the view that it is desirable that creditors should receive substantially the same treatment, irrespective of whether the debtor is an individual or a company. The proposed amendments to the Bankruptcy Act will achieve a degree of uniformity with the corresponding provisions of the Companies Act, creating certainty in the business community, and the proposed amendments are desirable for that reason. The third area of the changes relates to improving the administration of the system. There are several minor administrative improvements which will be implemented by this Bill.

In summary, the amendments probably fall into three categories. Firstly, the amendments will assist the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy to obtain reports from registered trustees and, by that means, facilitate the preparation by the Inspector-General of his annual report on the operation of the Bankruptcy Act and his other statistical duties. Secondly, the amendments will allow the Inspector-General to apply to the Federal Court for an inquiry into the conduct of a trustee. Thirdly, the amendments will provide the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department, rather than the Governor-General, with power to appoint people to the statutory offices created by the Act. It is, in substance, a routine task which need not necessarily be imposed on the Governor-General. The Opposition, therefore, supports that particular amendment, as it does the other amendments in this area of administrative improvement.

The fourth area can be described as the removal of anomalies. Amendments to the Bankruptcy Act have been prepared to remove anomalies in the Act which are now apparent in the light of earlier amendments to the Act. In relation to the Common Investment Fund, introduced by the Bankruptcy Amendment Act l980, amendments are now proposed of a machinery and non-controversial nature. One section relating to the maintenance of bank accounts for each bankruptcy district creates an unnecessary work load where a number of districts are administered by the same Official Receiver. The proposed amendment will reduce the inefficiency associated with the present wording of the section by allowing consolidation of bank accounts for two or more districts with the same Official Receiver.

A second proposed amendment relates to the payment of moneys into and out of the equalisation account, which is a fund for interest earned by the Common Investment Fund. The present wording of section 20H does not satisfactorily direct when the first and subsequent determinations should be made of the amounts to be paid to Consolidated Revenue and the amounts to be retained to meet possible calls to a bankrupt estate or some other person entitled to moneys in the Fund.

The proposed amendment is expected to correct this anomaly by requiring the Common Investment Fund Investment Board to so decide at such times as it considers appropriate and at least once every six months.

An amendment of a similar non-controversial nature, but nevertheless one which should be mentioned, is that to section l25 of the Act which ensures that the control which can be exercised by the trustee over bank accounts of an undischarged bankrupt, preventing the dissipation of assets held in that account, can also be exercised over accounts with other financial institutions, such as building societies and credit unions. The proposed amendment to section 64 of the Act is of like character and defers the holding of a creditors meeting until after a statement of affairs has been filed. In most cases it is pointless to hold a creditors meeting until details of the creditors of the bankrupt and the moneys owed to them are known. The amendment is expected to improve the administration of the Act by requiring the holding of the first creditors meeting once the statement has been filed, rather than within a certain time from the bankruptcy. The Opposition supports these amendments, which are designed to improve the operation of the Act by overcoming some of the problems which have arisen in the Act's machinery. But it is here substantially that the sense of consensus, if that is the appropriate word, comes to an end.

Although it is true to say that we have given our support to the vast bulk of the amendments, the last area relating to the modification of the Review of Commonwealth Functions decision is one where we must make some comments which are of a somewhat critical nature. The most important provision in the Bill deals with modifications to those amendments which were introduced by the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Act l98l. These are the provisions of the Bill which were instituted from the reports of the former Government's Review of Commonwealth Functions, which implemented what is commonly known as privatisation of the bulk of bankrupt estates administration. Prior to l98l virtually all bankrupt estates were administered by the Official Receivers who, as honourable members are no doubt aware, are public servants operating under the control of the Official Trustee. This situation arose because, under the legislation as it existed at that time, the courts were required, upon the hearing of a creditor's or debtor's petition, to appoint the Official Receiver as the administrator of all bankrupt estates. However, there was provision for the appointment of a private registered trustee, usually a practising accountant, if the first meeting of the creditors so determined. That option was rarely exercised because private trustees were prohibited from soliciting or advertising the availability of their services. Accordingly, in l98l only l3 out of 5,l54 estates under bankruptcy administration were administered by private trustees.

The Review of Commonwealth Functions changed all of that. The l98l legislation introduced a scheme which, first of all, maintained the existing system for all estates valued at less than $l0,000, so that the court was compelled to appoint an Official Receiver for those estates, although at the first meeting of creditors a registered trustee could be substituted. Secondly, it introduced a scheme in respect of all estates valued at more than $l0,000. It was mandatory in these cases that a private registered trustee be appointed to administer the estate. With this change, the role of private trustees grew rapidly and this was one of the momentous decisions made as part of the Review of Commonwealth Functions which saw some significant changes in the landscape of this country. By way of a comment on the side, it was unfortunate that there were not more who were able to see that increasing the role of the free and private sector of the economy added some strength to it. To return to bankruptcy, the situation was that in l982-83 some l,063 out of 5,l56 estates under bankruptcy administration were administered by registered trustees and it is fair to say that in general the overwhelming majority of registered trustees have undertaken their duties with dedication and skill. Insofar as this Bill seeks what is referred to as a modification of the Review of Commonwealth Functions decision, it operates at two levels. First, the Government is putting the proposition that, following the privatisation of bankruptcy administration, private trustees have failed in their duties to report and investigate. In his second reading speech on last year's Bill, Senator Gareth Evans, who was then the Attorney-General, said:

Some trustees have engaged in distinctly unprofessional conduct; statistics indicate that many trustees, even most trustees, do not take seriously the investigative and reporting duties which the Act imposes on the trustee . . .

We heard some echoes of those remarks in the statement made by the current Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in this House today. The Government's solution to this perceived problem is a group of amendments to be made by this Bill which will impose stringent reporting and investigatory functions upon private trustees. The Opposition, in fact, does not accept the Government's rationale for these changes. However, we will not oppose them because they go to solving the only problem which has been recognised as arising from the privatisation of bankruptcy administration. If the changes are to be made-and we will not oppose the proposed changes-it would seem logical that there is no objection to maintaining the substantial privatisation of this particular area of commercial activity. In other words, if that prop is taken away from the Government's case, we can see no reason why substantial privatisation should not remain.

We wish to emphasise the point that the Opposition rejects the Government's allegation-an allegation which Senator Gareth Evans again took the opportunity recently to repeat in the Senate-that most private trustees have been derelict and are guilty of professional misconduct. We note that the Insolvency Practitioners Association of Australia, which is a body of private registered trustees, has taken the Government to task on this particular allegation which has been made against its members. It has noted that all registered trustees are required by the terms of the existing legislation to have had prior experience in insolvency matters and that most have derived their experience as company auditors and liquidators. Further, the Association goes on to say this in a submission:

Accordingly, such persons are professional accountants with a background of investigation into the financial affairs of businesses and corporate entities. It is common place, however, that the reporting has developed in the accounting profession of matters of exception rather than on reporting conformity.

The Association goes on to assert that private trustees do, in fact, conduct investigations but they file reports only when matters warrant further investigation, which is the way one would have thought they would conduct their profession.

We say that, if the investigation is a problem, the amendments proposed in this Bill will alleviate that problem and will allow the privatisation to continue as a success because that is the only defect that has been pointed to. For this reason the Opposition really cannot understand why the second stage of the modifications of the Review of Commonwealth Functions decision will be to get rid of the privatisation of bankruptcy administration. In the second reading speech on last year's Bill, Senator Gareth Evans said that the Government sought to implement a reversal, as he called it, of the Review of Commonwealth Functions decision. If that Bill had gone ahead there would have been a reversion to the l98l situation where the courts would have been required to appoint an Official Receiver in every case but with the right vested in the first meeting of creditors to reverse that decision.

This Bill speaks only of a modification, not a reversal of the RCF decision, but its result will be the same. The Bill will repeal the privatisation of the administration of bankrupt estates valued at more than $l0,000. As with the l984 Bill, this Bill will make it compulsory for the courts to appoint an Official Receiver. Our view is that it is surprising that the Government has offered no real explanation for this reversal or modification, call it what one will, if the only problem with the privatisation has concerned the failure to report and investigate and when other provisions of this Bill, which we support, will solve those difficulties. On that basis there is no reason for terminating the privatisation, which has been operating for only four years, when private trustees are just beginning to develop real expertise in this area.

We will oppose these provisions on that basis. Although we will not delay the House by calling for a division, I simply put on record that we do object to those provisions in clauses l5 and l7 of the Bill.

Another comment I wish to make relates to this somewhat optimistic financial impact statement in the second reading speech. We know that, according to some foreign magazines, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is the world's best Treasurer and the Government keeps reminding us of this fact, although less frequently over the last few weeks than it did previously. That it can perform a feat of financial gymnastics by putting an extra 42 staff on the payroll and as a result save $777,000 over and above its current level of expenditure really is a most remarkable proposition. If for no reason other than curiosity, we will give very close scrutiny to the future Budget appropriations for the Attorney-General's Department to see how it is going along with this plan.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it appoints more that will cost it even less, will it?

—We will have to wait to see exactly what form it takes. We all know that when governments appoint 47 temporary employees, as we are told is the situation in this case, they are not going to achieve their savings by sacking them and sending them out on the street. Whatever happens, that certainly is not going to happen. So we are at a loss to see how a saving of $777,000 is going to come about as a result of appointing 42 extra, and presumably permanent, employees in the Department administering this area of the law. We will wait with great interest to see how that comes about.

SPEECH.PARA: The final point I make is that if savings can be effected so readily in the Department, even if only in this mythical way by which they are plucked out of the air when it suits the Government's convenience, one might ask rhetorically why those economies could not be effected anyway without waiting for an opportunity where the Government is forced to say, as it does in this debate, that it is appointing extra staff but there will be no extra cost involved. If the matter were logical, it seems that there would be a case for reducing government expenditure very substantially by appointing more public servants, a proposition which again is interesting and which we might pursue on another occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Previous speakers have referred to a number of intended amendments to this legislation. I wish to highlight two or three aspects which I believe have an important community impact. One to which I shall refer in a moment is the impact on maintenance payments with respect to bankrupt estates. The other refers to priority payments in areas such as workers compensation, entitlements to leave and wages payments-in a sense, debts due to employees. I will begin with the amendment which in effect enables the trustee to ensure that the control that can be exercised over bank accounts of an undischarged bankrupt can also be exercised over accounts with financial institutions other than banks. This legislation is designed to do a number of things with respect to amending bankruptcy law. Honourable members will be aware that we are also trying to bring bankruptcy law, which essentially applies to individuals, into line with company law, which of course applies to corporations. As far as certain areas of the legislation are concerned, the intention is very clear. We are trying to line up provisions in the companies code with bankruptcy provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: To turn to the first item to which I referred, the trustee will now be able to deal with accounts other than bank accounts. In the past it was very difficult for the Official Trustee in Bankruptcy to deal with those sums of money that were in accounts in financial institutions other than banks. Clause 25 of this legislation proposes an amendment to section l25 of the Act which will ensure that the Official Trustee in Bankruptcy will have the capacity to deal with sums in financial institutions other than banks. Of course, it will apply similarly to bank accounts but it will, if honourable members like, spread the reach of the Official Trustee in Bankruptcy.

There is another sensible amendment in clause 20 of the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill, which proposes an amendment to section 64 relating to the first meeting of creditors. This will defer the need for a first meeting until after a statement of affairs has been filed. Quite clearly, it is futile to have a meeting when a statement of affairs is not available. This amendment in a sense says: 'Let's get a statement of affairs ready, and when we have that we can have a meeting of creditors'. That is a simple procedural amendment which is a common-sense approach. The clause with respect to maintenance creditors is one that I believe is of substantial concern to the community. The report of the National Maintenance Inquiry entitled 'A Maintenance Agency for Australia' states at paragraph l.53:
If a respondent is sufficiently determined the payment of maintenance can be made a voluntary act.

Quite clearly, that is the case with respect to many women in the community. I specifically refer to the plight of women under family law arrangements, where it has been very difficult in certain circumstances to enforce maintenance orders. In those circumstances it has been the dependent spouse-in most cases, of course, dependent women-who has suffered due to the other spouse becoming bankrupt and thereby removing funds from her grasp. In a sense in this clause we are trying to make it more possible for the Trustee in Bankruptcy to get access to those funds. Clause 3 will clarify the definition of maintenance order by removing any doubt that the term includes an order for arrears of maintenance. The trustee will now be in a position to deal more easily with this area of social concern of arrears of maintenance as well as with maintenance orders generally.

The changes proposed in this Bill will alleviate in part the difficulties confronting a maintenance creditor endeavouring to recover arrears of maintenance. Clearly, this legislation recognises that difficulties have been encountered in the past. It has been possible for the breakdown of a marriage to occur and then for a bankruptcy arrangement to be established in which usually the former wife no longer has access to funds in order to carry out the maintenance of her family because the former husband has been able to remove those funds from the grasp of the trustee through the bankruptcy arrangements. It seems to me that the more we look at this issue the more important it is that we recognise it is of social concern.

I want to dwell also on concerns with a number of arrangements applying to employees. I refer in particular to the operations of the building industry. Quite frequently it is possible for employees to be completely left out of creditor arrangements. We find that due to personal guarantee arrangements between the owner of the building company and other suppliers some suppliers can be satisfied through creditor arrangements, but very often the people who miss out are the employees who are due certain long service leave, superannuation and wage entitlements.

I believe we as a community ought to look at arrangements that prevail in certain countries where employers are obliged to take out long service leave entitlements for their employees in the form of a payment for stamps. In the case of a winding up the funds have already been appropriated by the firm and the creditor has access to a pool of funds. The employees, who would otherwise miss out on entitlements due to the maladministration of a company, then have access to those funds. Quite clearly, with respect to bankruptcies, it is a matter of concern that very often employees are the ones who miss out.

I am pleased to note in regard to certain issues such as leave entitlements that clause 23 (f) of this legislation, dealing with priority payments, is intended to line this legislation up with the Companies Act. In a number of areas, with respect to leave entitlements and workers compensation, this legislation is designed to try to line up with the Companies Act, to try to make, in a sense, a more orderly procedure for dealing with employees' entitlements. Very often, one of the reasons that we have difficulties in certain industries is the activities of fly-by-night operators who get into a business and conduct it in a fairly haphazard way and when that business goes into bankruptcy the people who miss out are employees. As a consequence, we get an increasing militancy by employees who seek, through their own arrangements, to ensure that when they go into a job they are pushing as hard a bargain as possible. It does not help the conduct of good industrial relations, because we get a dog-eat-dog situation. I am suggesting that, in considering areas such as bankruptcy, if we can provide for effective protection of employees we will go a long way towards improving the climate between employees and employers.

The substance of my comments relates to a number of things. First, with respect to some of the amendments entailed, where this legislation is designed to parallel the arrangements in the Companies Code, some appropriate arrangements are made with respect to priority payments for employees. I refer to leave entitlements and workers compensation arrangements-I believe that is very important-as well as debts due to employees. They are important areas.

In summing up, I make the following points: This legislation brings forward a number of amendments. One amendment that I believe is important is the attempt to clarify from the point of view of the Official Trustee in Bankruptcy the question of maintenance orders. Very clearly, there is a concern in the community, where many women in particular have suffered because of bankruptcy arrangements. The other area which I believe is of benefit is the amendment which extends the coverage by the trustee to accounts in financial institutions other than bank accounts.

Finally, it is quite important that we try to provide adequate protection for employees in the event of bankruptcies. Clearly, employees very often miss out in those arrangements. I shall elaborate very briefly. With respect to the Companies Code in the building industry, one can make a very strong case for saying that we ought to be establishing a common fund whereby builders are obliged to lodge bond payments so that they can set up operations. There is a proliferation of defaults in the building industry where people are having extensions done to their properties, having some other changes in their housing or are having a house built, and the company defaults on them. Many people have no protection in the community as they have in other areas of industry. For example, among solicitors and other such groups, such as the insurance group, there is a capacity for a common fund. It would make a lot of sense to have a common fund for building operations so that when there are defaults the aggrieved customer can call upon that common fund and get some redress. At the moment that is absent. In New South Wales and Victoria a bonding arrangement has been developed. I certainly see a case for it being developed in other States. In my State of Western Australia I see a considerable case for that.
I believe that the amendments intended in this legislation are sensible. They will bring some common sense into the conduct of bankruptcy. I commend them to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the presence of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in the chamber. I intend to refer to the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill and to the processes of bankruptcy, citing one instance which concerns a constituent of mine, and drawing to the Attorney-General's attention factors which are still not included in the legislation. I refer in particular to the role of the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy and his powers and the way he can apply them. Under the Bill, the powers of the Inspector-General are somewhat extended. I am pleased to see that. His role has slightly changed. He has a greater specification of function and a greater opportunity to ensure on behalf of the Commonwealth that the progress of a bankruptcy case can be dealt with properly and effectively.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there are some areas in early clauses of the Bill which deal with the role of the Inspector-General that I would like the Attorney to consider. I refer him to clause 4 and the amendments proposed to section l2 of the Bankruptcy Act. The role of the Inspector-General is specified under proposed new paragraphs b (i), b (ii), b (iii), b (iv) and b (v). If one refers to the original Act, one sees that those paragraphs relate to the role of the Inspector-General, to the process of bankruptcy to which he can apply his mind and the minds of his officers. I see some deficiencies in that approach because I find that Division 2 of Part X, for instance, which deals with meetings of creditors, control of debtors' property and so on, is not an area to which generally the Inspector-General has access.

There is a process to protect the trustee's accounts and the making good of losses sustained by negligence, which can be referred to a court. That is proper and right. However, in the examples that I intend to give, there are still areas where the Inspector-General should have a right to assess the validity of creditors who are accepted by a trustee-the processes of minutes and meetings of creditors, areas related to the initial impetus when the trustee becomes involved in a bankruptcy case, the election of chairmen, adjournments, entitlement to vote, restriction on voting by proxy; all sorts of factors which a trustee has control of and, in fact, may not be supervised by the Inspector-General. I should like the Attorney to clarify that point for me because I cannot find within the Bill any provisions which extend the Inspector-General's powers into those areas. In fact, in one clause at a later stage, concerning the hearing in public, the powers of the trustee are such that there are no hearings in public unless the Official Receiver intervenes and says that he wants to have a hearing in public.

I wish to draw to the Attorney-General's attention the case of Latona. I know that he is aware of the case and I have here three thick files that I have accumulated during the progress of these affairs. The participants in this case are active, dynamic and forthright to the extreme in some circumstances. It is a very hotly contested process and my constituent, Mr Latona, is certainly very forceful in expressing himself, both to me and to everybody else. I have noticed that in the processing of his case before a trustee there are particular areas that spark action and that have created real difficulty. The admittance of creditors to a meeting has been a real factor. In discussions with the Inspector-General it appears that that is not an area where he currently can have much impact. Neither does it appear that the Registrar is able to intervene in the admittance of creditors. If that is not the case under the present law, it should be the case under the proposed law, and if it were possible under the existing law, something should have been done to clear up the matter of who were creditors in this case. The previous Attorney-General is fully aware of the case. The details were known to him. He instigated an inquiry by Mr Drennan to assess the case and Mr Drennan reported on it.

The admittance of creditors is a spark point. I draw the attention of the Government to that area in particular. The Latona case in fact highlights some of the difficulties. Providing the minutes on the progress of meetings, reporting to the registrar and hence to the bankrupt individual and providing information concerning the progress of the sale or disposal of the estate are steps which to the best of my knowledge have not been carried out in this instance. This matter has been in progress over a period of 18 months. No one is aware officially of what property has been sold at what price or to whom. I understand that in fact it may not be a requirement to inform the bankrupt of that process, but somebody ought to know that the thing is going properly and be able to vouch for the process of the sale of assets.

In the Latona case that apparently has not happened and it is of great concern to me. Mr Latona has been to see me on numerous occasions and has forcefully presented me with a valuation of his estate made by his own accountant. There may be some qualifications on the values that he has put on his estate but reputable valuers have carried out the valuations for him. It appears to me that the estate was disposed of at a price $800,000 or $900,000 less than the current market value. I regard that as being fairly serious. In relation to one property in particular, at Mackerel Beach, I will read for the Attorney-General an advertisement which appeared in Sydney newspapers about the property. An advertisement in the Sydney Morning Herald of 16 February stated:
Mackerel Beach. Lot 128 Diggers Crescent. Residential block with dilapidated home. Land value only. See auction columns today.

That is a description of the property from an agent in Rockdale. That is nowhere near Mackerel Beach, which is in the Palm Beach area. I understand the reserve price was $36,000, though another valuation was made by the trustee of $47,000. It is claimed that the property was sold at auction, after a number of bids, for $47,000. Anybody with a knowledge of that area and the house in particular would have to value property in this select area at a much greater amount than that because the Valuer-General's value for just the land was $60,000. There are certificates to show that. In this instance the valuation set, I understand, by the firm of Hookers and another independent valuer, was about $l00,000 to $ll0,000.

This process of disposal is something that the Inspector-General has to be able to deal with. I believe that under these amendments he can deal with these processes and he ought to be able to investigate something that is improper. I further draw to the attention of the Attorney-General Dun's Gazette for New South Wales, week No. l0 at page l5, where the following reference to the trustee in the Latona case appears:

Aitken Hargreaves and Turner (Aitken Lindsay Robert) l23 Clarence Street Sydney and 772A Henry Lawson Dve Picnic Point chartered accountant on petition of Trans-Tasman Timbers P/L. For hearing on 11/3/84.

It appears to me, as a non-legal entity but following discussion with lawyers, that the trustee himself in this instance is also under threat of bankruptcy. I do not know how that case can go on or how he can remain in that position. It may be legitimate and proper that he do so. It does not appear to me that that is a proper process of the law or the intention of the previous Government or this Government in regard to trustees of estates.

I believe the decision to register trustees was a good one but the way in which they operate must be properly scrutinised and supervised. The Government has moved in this legislation to tighten up some of those areas in which the Inspector-General may investigate matters but I do not believe it has gone far enough in some respects. The Government has attended to the special provisions applicable to deeds of assignment, to the special provisions applicable to deeds of arrangement, to the special provisions applicable to compositions, to the administration of estates of deceased persons and to a number of other areas which are picked up in the legislation before the House in clause 4(a), clause 4 (b) and clause 4 (ba).

I refer this matter to the Attorney-General because it has worried me for a long time. There was sufficient concern for the former Attorney-General to appoint a special investigator, whose report I have read and whose description of the problem does not quite match the conclusions he drew. I was sufficiently concerned at one stage to wonder whether the Commissioner of Police should be informed of this matter for I feared that some Commonwealth officers may have been involved in matters that were not proper. I have no evidence to conclude that they may have been but it appears that the process of the disposal over l8 months of an estate of over $2m if we take the broadest valuation-that may not be a factual valuation-has been such that the proceeds will not pay for the trustee. The creditors will get nothing and the trustee himself will get part of his fee only. I do not know to whom the properties have been sold but I think it is worth investigation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I should say that this may be one of the very few times that the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) and I agree about certain aspects of policies and politics. I certainly agree that some of the administration in the area of bankruptcy is reason for concern. Of course, the honourable member for Mitchell was not present when the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown) was pointing out the Opposition's disagreement with the amendments proposed by the Government to clause l0 of the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill and to section l9 of the Act, which will bring the private trustees under some control by the Official Receiver. The reason that the honourable member for Mitchell gave, and the concern that he has expressed, is the very reason why these changes should take place and why the Opposition should not oppose such amendments. It should support them in order that private trustees can be placed under some degree of control and investigations can be made into the conduct of individuals suspected of dishonest conduct.

SPEECH.PARA: Bankruptcy is of prime importance to many members of the Australian community. As an example of that, in l982-83 some l2,000 people entered into bankruptcy in Australia and if we go beyond the bankrupts themselves and look at the people who are affected as, including creditors and members of families, obviously every year in Australia large numbers of people are affected by Federal bankruptcy legislation. It might be of interest to note that the level of bankruptcy in Queensland has grown at a rate almost twice that of any other State. I was interested during the matter of public importance debate earlier to see that the Opposition was not at all concerned with the social ills and problems being caused in Queensland by the grave mismanagement of the Queensland economy and the bankruptcy and social problems which flow from that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Driven into bankruptcy by the unions.

—I am sure what is happening to the Queensland economy will be reflected in the economic statistics and indicia, which we can all read. This Bill is of great importance. It recognises the Government's commitment to a wide review of the operation of the Bankruptcy Act l966. I have indicated that bankruptcy is of great social importance in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government of course is looking at a wider reform by referring further aspects of the bankruptcy legislation to the Law Reform Commission. The bankruptcy process affects values inherent in a credit consumer-oriented society. Morality, skill and knowledge are important values in their own right.

There has been very little attempt in this country to work out a coherent bankruptcy philosophy. The committees that have been appointed have made little impact or contribution to the theory underlying it. Bankruptcy to many, who through no act of dishonesty seek its protection, is seen as an act of desperation; an act of last choice. I have seen many individuals forced to the realisation of bankruptcy. I have seen the shame of people who have filed for bankruptcy and who see it as an act of degradation to themselves and their pride. Yet bankruptcy is not simply a matter of collecting and distributing money for creditors. The point that the honourable member for Mitchell made-I believe that he did not quite express it in the terms that he was wanting to express it-is that it appears to bankrupts and to some creditors that the present system of bankruptcy law in this country operates only to satisfy the cost requirements of the trustees and the creditors.

There is a greater social philosophy involved in bankruptcy-there should be more recognition of this philosophy-that is, the problems faced by the bankrupt himself. We live in a community where, daily, vast sums of advertising money are being spent on radio, television and in the newspapers to encourage people to enter into a consumer society and to borrow money. One can sit down any night, watch television and see continually the promotion of the great Australian dream of buying a boat, a holiday house, a second car, or a four-wheel drive recreation vehicle. People are constantly being urged to buy on credit. Statistics show us very clearly that Australia is now becoming a nation of borrowers. The debt per family is rising increasingly. The legislation which solves these problems is the bankruptcy legislation.

Let us just stop and think about the vast amount of money being spent by the advertising industry. It employs top industrial psychologists to weave its clever messages through the advertising medium. Yet the amount of money which we spend on counselling and rehabilitative processes for those people who are sucked in by the advertising process is next to zero. Very little money is being spent on debt counselling. At present the Act does not give those people who find themselves in financial difficulties very much option. It does not give them the option of seeking a counselling service and program which will avoid the shame and degradation of bankruptcy. It does not allow them to enter into a debt reconciliation program. It offers a very stark reality: If a person cannot pay his debts, his creditors hound him to death-let us face it; quite often, rightly, the creditors should be hounding people for their payments-and that person goes bankrupt.

The moment he goes bankrupt, what happens? A private operator now takes control of the assets of the bankrupt. As the honourable member for Mitchell rightly pointed out, no one bothers to tell the bankrupt what is going on. The bankrupt is the last person to find out. Any professional person works firstly to get his fees and income. He is not there to look after the bankrupt and initially he is not there to look after the creditors. His primary function in bankruptcy is to make sure that he will get paid. That is why the legislation makes sure that the trustee is the first person who gets paid. So where is the incentive for, or the control upon, the trustee to act in the interests of the bankrupt in the rehabilitative process or to act in the interests of the creditor?

One can find many examples, looking through bankruptcy procedures and practice in this country, where one can question the valuations placed upon bankrupts assets which are being sold. I share the concern of the honourable member for Mitchell very much in this area. I have had many instances where clients have come to me and said: 'I have gone into bankruptcy. I have had a trustee appointed. I own these assets. The trustee has taken them all. I cannot find out what has happened to them. I have seen one of them advertised for sale. I know that it is worth more than the price asked for. I have tried to see the trustee to explain that that asset is worth more and the trustee says: ''Son, you are bankrupt. Go away. I am the legal owner of your property. I am acting for the creditors and I will sell it at my price'' '. I think all members of this House should be very concerned about the process which takes away the dignity of the bankrupt and which does not give the creditors much control over the actions of the trustee.

I am pleased that to this legislation no amendment is proposed by the Opposition. The Opposition will support some control over the privatisation of trustees. The actual amendments to this legislation are quite complex. In fact, bankruptcy law is quite specialised law. Very few people in private practice, either in the accounting profession or in the legal profession, can profess to have any great knowledge of the technicality of bankruptcy law. That is a great pity. As a lawyer I have attempted many times to understand some of the complex terms in the legislation. I find it very difficult to read and I find it very difficult to come to grips with in interpretive terms.

The Bankruptcy Amendment Bill before the House is to be recommended. I commend the Bill to the House. My great concern is the further reform for which we must look. That reform will come only when the Law Reform Commission, which has been commissioned by this Government to have a total overview of bankruptcy law, reports to this House. When we get that report I believe that we can very properly start looking at the propositions for rehabilitative processes and for care and concern for those people who find themselves bankrupt. I can commend many organisations in Victoria. I know that a debt counselling service has been established in Broadmeadows with the co-operation of the Broadmeadows municipality and supported by funds from the Victorian Government. It is doing a sterling job for people who find themselves caught by a debt crisis in a consumer-oriented society. If many bankrupts had proper counselling and services provided they would find that they would not have to go into the bankruptcy process. They would try to avoid the personal shame of bankruptcy which so many people feel and they would try to pay their debts. I look forward to that further reform and I look forward to the report of the Law Reform Commission.

Briefly, I note the fallacy of the Opposition's concern at the amendments which will give the Official Receiver control over the private trustees. I find that admirable. In fact, I think there should be a greater examination of the way in which the private trustees are operating to see whether they are operating to recover their own costs or those of a minority of creditors. I can certainly tell honourable members that, from my experience, they do not have any concern for the bankrupt himself. I support the amendments contained in the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill is before the House I would like to raise a couple of matters of considerable concern to me in relation to the administration of the Bankruptcy Act. These matters relate to two constituents of mine whom I choose not to name in this House. Both constituents are residents of similar towns. They came to see me at different times regarding the treatment they received when they went to see the Registrar in Bankruptcy, they claim, seeking advice because of their financial circumstances. My action in this regard was to refer the matters to the Commonwealth Ombudsman who conducted an inquiry and generally found that there was nothing in these complaints. However, in one letter to me the Ombudsman said:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe Mr Hedges informed you that we have had several current complaints relating to bankruptcy matters . . .

Clearly, my two constituents' complaints were not the only complaints in this regard. The situations regarding my two constituents were very similar. Both were in business and both were in some financial difficulty; of that there was no doubt. Nevertheless, both were in a situation where most of their debt was in the form of hire purchase or lease agreements which were not immediately significant. Clearly, at that time, both of them could not see themselves as being able to handle the continuing and ongoing payments. As I understand it, neither of them was very much behind with their payments to the finance companies. One constituent had accumulated outstanding debts of about $7,000 and the other a larger amount.

Nevertheless, both claim that, having taken some advice from a legal person in their town-a lawyer, I gather-they were told that they should go and talk to the Registrar in Bankruptcy. Both of them did this at different times and both told a similar story. Both claim that they were seeking a deed of assessment, which I believe might have been a deed of assignment. That is just the first piece of evidence of how ordinary people, small people, small business people, are not qualified in this regard. Having gone there thinking that they were going to get such a thing-I presume their legal adviser told them they could do something of this nature-they were told at the bankruptcy section on the ninth floor that they should fill out certain documents which, in fact, were affidavits. They claim that, after filling them out, they were told: 'You are now declared bankrupt'. When they protested they were advised that if they wanted to take the matter to the High Court or the Supreme Court and pay some $2,000 they could get out of this position. In fact, in my original interview with one, I noted that a High Court action was required. Again, they might not be the correct words.

The reality of both these situations is that immediately there was a bankruptcy action the hire purchase companies descended to recover their equipment. I am told that the truck they had purchased for $58,000 on an $18,000 deposit was sold for $16,000 and that a house they had purchased for $36,000 and on which they claim to have done considerable upgrading was sold for $26,000. We know that in many of these situations that is the way it can be, but my complaint is that although the Ombudsman has accepted the evidence of the various officers, and I cannot dispute that, my constituents say it happened differently. I accepted the genuine approach of both these people. I point out that in one other piece of correspondence from the Ombudsman, which I have not got, it was implied that their original answer to the Ombudsman in Western Australia was: 'Look, we are in the bankruptcy business; we are not in the advice business. Everyone who comes through our door wants to be bankrupted'. I was pretty disappointed about that.

This raises the issue, which might be brought before this Parliament by the Government on future occasions, of the different means by which people in these circumstances may be able to deal with their debts. From my own assessment, having had the facts and figures put before me, I would have said that these people were not candidates for bankruptcy. I would have said that they were candidates for a creditors' meeting. They were both hard-working people. The district they were servicing was suffering from drought and other circumstances. One man was an agricultural contractor and the other a cartage contractor carting into the town and they had had some difficulties. I believe that with good seasons and a kind-hearted approach from the finance companies and some of their other creditors, who I admit were not large, things might have been different. Finance companies are not always painted as being kind-hearted. Sometimes I growl at them and sometimes I talk to them, but on numerous occasions I have found that the finance companies are prepared to assist people when there is evidence that it is not laziness or other things which have brought about their circumstances.

I am sure that if some independent counselling had been available at the bankruptcy office to these people they could have been advised to have a creditors' meeting. It may be, with the interest we now have in small business, that somebody, perhaps an accountant, needed to talk to their creditors for them. These people, for reasons unknown to me, were probably ill-advised by their first adviser about going to the bankruptcy office. I am sure that had they come to me, for instance, I could have talked to their creditors and come to an arrangement. In the period they were in that office-one did go away and come back-both of them were literally bankrupted on their first visit. I am sure that this is something we need to look at.

The Ombudsman and the Attorney-General's Department have responded. All the things they have said are probably quite correct. It is interesting to note that the Attorney-General's Department points out that there are reasons why a debtor may have to be dealt with promptly, and maybe that is so. These people just did not seem to tell me that story. It also points out how busy some of these officers are. In their defence they claim that if they have rushed someone through the system it may be because they were too busy. I would be very happy to make available to the Attorney-General the information on the case and the response from the Ombudsman. I do not really think that, as the system exists, these people were necessarily hard done by. I just think that within the system there is a need to consider how we can better advise people who just do not understand. I believe that in this case both of these people did not understand that they were being sent bankrupt at the time. Naturally that has been denied. The officers claim that they spelt it all out; but, whether it was spelt out to these people or not, they did not understand that they were bankrupt. They both lost their homes and their vehicles and they have been put in very difficult circumstances which, from my judgment, should not have been necessary.

I would ask the Attorney-General, in framing future legislation, to think to some extent on what the Ombudsman has suggested; that is, that there is room for a cooling-off period, in the same way that, when buying encyclopaedias, a person can change his mind in a day or so. Okay, but surely that can still be handled by a counsellor. People can talk to a counsellor and be told: 'In your case, you have these pressing needs'.
Mr Brazil, from the Attorney-General's Department, in a letter to me, stated:
Generally speaking, if a debtor were to complain during interview that he had become bankrupt by mistake, I would expect the interviewing officer to:
explain to the debtor what is the meaning and effect of the above provision;
discontinue the interview, at least for the time being; and
allow the debtor a reasonable time (say 7 days) to decide whether he wanted to make an application to the Court for annulment under section 154.

Nevertheless, it seems quite strange that people who do not know what they are doing can sign a piece of paper which is irreversible at that stage. TALK.START.PARA: —I will take only a few minutes of the House's time this evening in the debate on the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill to deal with one or two aspects of the vexed question of bankruptcy. I agreed with most of what was said by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who preceded me in this debate. I understand the sorts of problems he raised and I think that he dealt with them sensitively. I hope that future legislation that will be forthcoming in the House dealing with debt repayment schemes will help to assist the sorts of problems to which he was referring.

SPEECH.PARA: In some of the Canadian provinces there are particularly detailed provisions dealing with those types of problems-in a sense, dealing with the problem before it gets to bankruptcy-which I think we could well adopt in this country. Some of the provinces have divided bankruptcies into petty bankruptcies and major bankruptcies, determined by an amount of money. One is much more likely to find insolvency fraud in large bankruptcies than in the type of bankruptcy that occurs in the under $200,000 insolvency category. I hope that in the near future, when legislation is brought before the Parliament, we will be able to deal with some of those matters. I intend to say one or two things further about that in my comments tonight.

Dealing with this Bill, I state that the reform of the Australian bankruptcy laws is, of course, long overdue. In many ways the assumptions, especially in the area of personal bankruptcies and insolvency which do not involve business debts, are those of an era when private property, speculation and the interests of investors and traders were considered paramount to the interests of individuals. These assumptions belong to another era. There should be no place in the l980s for the ruin of Australian families who are caught up in the debt spiral. The Australia in which we live is a country which has been characterised by wealth and affluence, especially since World War II, but is also a country which has been characterised by unnecessary and indeed unjustifiable disparities in wealth and affluence. Our bankruptcy and insolvency laws do little to alleviate these problems. They do not acknowledge that economic recession, the evil of unemployment, the effects of social pressures and continued increased consumption can have an effect on the degree and extent of bankruptcy and insolvency that we find in the community at large. Instead, essentially they blame the victims-the victims of economic circumstances often well beyond their control, of socialisation, of inadequate training and of lack of information. Governments in Australia have not done enough to remedy this situation.

Over l0 years ago, the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty identified the extent of poverty in our community. In particular, it identified the problems of bankruptcy and insolvency. In l976, the Sixth Report of the Australian Law Reform Commission recommended a scheme-the Regular Payment of Debts Plan-to assist potential personal bankrupts or insolvents to overcome their economic and budgetary problems before the drastic step of bankruptcy was taken. Little has been done since to implement the recommendations of either report.

I am pleased to say that in l978 when I was Attorney-General in South Australia in the Dunstan Government I succeeded in legislating for a debts repayments scheme based on the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission. Unfortunately, before that scheme could be brought into effect, the Tonkin Government was elected and that Liberal Government chose not to proclaim that legislation; it still sits unproclaimed on the books in South Australia. It is a scandalous situation that something has not been done about that before now. The purpose of that legislation was to establish a scheme to help debtors in financial difficulties. It provided for the establishment of a debtors assistance office and for the appointment and training of debt counsellors. It was based on a scheme that exists in Saskatchewan. The whole idea is that, by cutting out legal costs, collection costs and other costs associated with debt at present, one can develop a sufficient pool of funds to cover nearly the costs of administration of the scheme. I understand that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) is working on introducing that sort of legislation into this Parliament so that such laws can apply throughout the Commonwealth. If we can achieve that, it will be very worth while.

It has always seemed to me anomalous that the laws relating to the insolvency of companies are largely dealt with under State law in this country whereas the laws relating to individual bankruptcies are dealt with under Commonwealth law. Although I have not researched the matter, my suspicion is that this may well have resulted as an accident from our constitutional fathers. Discussions aimed at possibly handing over to the States powers over minor bankruptcies and ensuring that the Commonwealth has powers over the major company insolvencies would be a worthwhile step. I do not know whether any discussion along those lines has taken place recently or in the past but I believe a rationalisation of the laws in this country would be well worth while.

I conclude by saying simply that the Bill that is before the House-I do not want to canvass the details of it because that has been done already by other speakers-is a good Bill and deserves the support of the Parliament, particularly clause 24 of the Bill which deals with debts due to employees. There have been numerous examples-too many to mention in detail-where a company has gone bankrupt and people who have worked for the company for many years have been denied their rights to long service leave and other accruing payments. This clause should ensure that that position will not arise in the future. I commend the Attorney-General for bringing forward a Bill which will remove that serious injustice, that serious anomaly. The Bill is a fair and proper one and, when it becomes law, it will ensure that the bankruptcy laws in this nation are at least fair and just. This review of the Bankruptcy Act, in my view, will go a long way to ensuring that bankruptcies, at least throughout the l980s, will be fair to all concerned. I congratulate the Attorney and I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Briefly, I thank honourable members for their contributions to this debate. The area of bankruptcy is virtually a no win area. As honourable members will understand, people who enter that arena are already in jeopardy. The point has been made by a number of speakers that the difficulties experienced by such people are not always alleviated. There is always concern about whether people receive fair value for their assets. In turn, of course, the creditors have to face the situation that they usually do not get paid in full. In the past under bankruptcy provisions, where people have legitimately entered trade and commerce and suffered losses through no real fault of their own, a genuine effort has been made, through a scheme of arrangement or a court order, to liquidate their debts and enable them to start again after a certain period but, during that period of bankruptcy, has prevented them from continuing in business.

SPEECH.PARA: I am interested in the remarks made by the honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan). I believe basically that in a modern society we ought to be looking at law reform in this area. It has been looked at and is still being looked at to see whether it can cover some of the matters raised in this debate. Although the Opposition supports the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill, the main speaker for the Opposition, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown), was critical of the fact that there appears to be some suggestion of competition between what is called the Official Receiver and private trustees. I think that is a good thing. If he looks at some of the other matters raised by subsequent speakers on his side, he will find that perhaps some of the difficulties related to the fact that trustees appointed privately were not as experienced as they should have been. I would like the honourable gentleman to look at the debate in the Senate on 27 March, at page 859 of Hansard, where he will see six examples given of trustees involved with over 400 estates. He will see that from the point of view of statistics it would be put down to inexperience but the difficulty was perhaps that the bankrupt people felt that they did not get proper treatment in the administration of their assets perhaps and the creditors felt that the matter had not been dealt with in a professional way. I am supported in that view by the fact that I am advised by my Department that the Insolvency Practitioners Association supports this Bill on that very basis. In other words, whilst a genuine effort was made to give the private sector a chance to do the work, experience has shown that it has not been done as well as it could have been in certain circumstances. I admit that there are very efficient private trustees.

I refer now to the contribution made by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). There was an example of what he regarded as inefficient administration, although whether it was I do not know. I would like him to address the fact that this legislation will assist in what he is about. He took the view that the Inspector-General perhaps will not be able to deal with a number of matters. However, the Inspector-General can deal with most matters, certainly all matters relating to bankruptcy. I would welcome a look at whether the Inspector-General will be able to deal with the question of who are deemed to be creditors and the question of voting. If he is not able to do so, perhaps he should be, because such matters directly relate to the conduct, administration and sequestration of the estate.

The Bill is progressive. It certainly covers a number of areas that perhaps have been weak. However, we will never overcome some of the difficulties which were mentioned, for example, by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who quite appropriately referred to the fact that perhaps some people had received wrong advice. Whether they did or not, we do not know. However, they certainly were made bankrupt. The difficulty, of course, in all these areas-I understand that it also applies to some of the assets referred to by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) in regard to the other case-is where there are registered mortgagees or hire purchase agreements. Once one starts to enter the area of bankruptcy the mortgagee will exercise powers of sale. I understand that that happened under some circumstances.

Of course there is also an obligation on the mortgagee exercising power of sale to get the best price. However, usually it is a forced sale and an urgent sale and it is usually made at the wrong time from the point of view of getting maximum price. One cannot altogether put the full blame on the trustee if, in fact, any asset has been sold by a mortgagee or an owner pursuant to a hire purchase agreement, which I think might have been the case with the matters referred to by the honourable member for O'Connor. I take the points of both gentlemen. Those cases ought to be looked at. I undertake to see what I can do so that we do not have what appears to be the failure of debtors to get maximum value for assets. That is important.

I say, with regard to the matters raised by the honourable member for O'Connor, that I think it is important that people who perhaps do not know their rights are given time to consult with their creditors rather than being made bankrupt in the first instance and then having the problem of everything being sold, which must happen once one is made bankrupt. That is the whole idea of bankruptcy. I will ask the Law Reform Commission to look at some of these matters because I am convinced that in a modern society we can think of better techniques than the present technique. I have a view, from my own period in practice, that the present technique is cumbersome and expensive and involves delays. There seems to be a gap between the bankrupt person and creditors being adequately catered for by being able to get some portion of their debt recouped. We have all those difficulties.

We will always have bad debts. We recognise that. However, it is important to try to help people at times to remain in business. Creditors are often very understanding. There is merit in suggesting that there might be consultation with creditors or in people getting some sort of advice from consultants or advisers in this field before bankruptcy is declared. In some cases it has to be declared rather quickly to protect assets. I thank everybody for their contribution to the debate. I must say, though, that the evidence even in this debate does not support what the honourable member for Menzies was emphasising, which is that there is necessarily great merit in the private trustee position. I make the point that there seem to be some difficulties involved in sustaining that point of view in the light of subsequent evidence given by other speakers.
