TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will assure the passage of the Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Bill, which provides a statutory basis for the Commonwealth's involvement in soil conservation. However, the Opposition is not committed to the establishment of a Soil Conservation Advisory Committee or to the statutory nature of this legislation. While the coalition is committed to direct Commonwealth financial assistance for soil conservation, it is not committed to legislation that tends to duplicate the role and the resources of State governments. For some years the Commonwealth has contributed to soil conservation, apart from a brief period when the Commonwealth contribution to the States was built into State revenue grants. The Fraser Government developed reservations about this earlier action. In the 1983 election campaign, for instance, the Liberal and National parties announced a new $5m afforestation and soil conservation program, with funding to rise to $15m in 1987-88. This program was aimed at building on the annual allocation to the States of more than $3m for soil conservation works. In addition, the Fraser Government provided for individual projects by landholders to be fully tax deductible in the year of expenditure. That went back as far as October 1980.

SPEECH.PARA: There is an important funding role for the Commonwealth Government in both water and soil conservation. Both resources are of paramount importance in any nation, but nowhere are these resources more important than in this arid, windswept continent. Soil resources are, of course, fundamental to future agricultural development and production. Agricultural production and the exports of our agricultural industries are of basic importance to the standard of living of all Australians. Unfortunately, in this urbanised society of ours, this fact of life is so often forgotten. All those people who take an interest in the future welfare of Australia must realise that the future of this nation depends very largely upon our capacity to produce from the soil of this nation.

This Bill should provide the statutory machinery for the efficient allocation of Commonwealth funds to soil conservation projects. It is of utmost important that every action is taken by the Commonwealth and State governments to conserve the limited and fragile soils that are needed to produce food and wealth for generations yet to come. The thin layer of topsoil is our greatest natural resource but already vast areas are experiencing soil degradation, and an effort must be made to overcome this damage. I agree with the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) that unless real and concerted efforts are made to save our soils, the economic welfare of Australia will be placed at grave risk. The problem is so important and national in character that States should not be left to tackle it alone. A national response is required in the long term interests of the nation. Therefore, the Opposition supports the aim of the program to develop and implement national policies for the rehabilitation and sustainable utilisation of the nation's soil and land resources. However, the policies must be developed in concert with the States and implemented with their concurrence.

There is also a need to encourage and involve the farmers' efforts in any program. Governments cannot do this task alone and farmers cannot do this task alone. Any worthwhile results will depend on the participation of the community at large. A satisfactory outcome will require all land users and all levels of government to accept their respective responsibilities in soil conservation. A considerable task remains to raise the level of public awareness of the need to prevent land degradation. I concede, however, that the great progress made over the last 10 years has been one of the notable developments that have occurred in this country. In the last 10 years there has been great progress in spite of droughts, but our task now is to build on that progress.

The Bill before the House establishes a Soil Conservation Advisory Committee, a trust fund and the conditions applying to grants. Future allocations of funds will be divided into three elements, namely, funding to the States, to individual projects and to Commonwealth departments. It is a matter of some concern, however, that no fixed appropriation has been allowed for in the Bill, so each year the Minister and his Department will do battle for funds, with no real certainty of success in their efforts. As one who has served in governments in a ministerial capacity for 10 years, I must say that it is very difficult for Ministers to win battles for projects such as soil conservation or, for that matter, water conservation. There always seem to be so many converging demands in a modern society. Social welfare claims, social welfare demands, the aspirations and the hopes of people in the arts and all sorts of areas seem to converge upon the government of the day. Very often some of the most important areas of development and conservation are forgotten in the struggle and the wrangling that go on for the dollars that are available in the Budget.

In 1983-84 the total allocation to soil conservation for a continent the size of the United States of America fell back sharply to $1m, despite Labor's 1983 campaign promise to allocate $4m in its first year in office. Only in this financial year has the allocation reached the $4m level that had been promised. What is $4m when all is said done? Many of the bridges in this country that cover little streams have cost $4m or more. We talk about $4m or $3m or $5m--

TALK.START.PARA: —What did your own Government spend? Nothing.

—I say to the honourable member for Capricornia that we introduced the program and we made an honest offer to the people of Australia to increase it on a scale that was never envisaged by the Australian Labor Party.
—What was your record?
—I think that the Labor Party's record stands to its discredit because in the first year it came into office it gave a miserable $1m to soil conservation.
—He was driven out of Queensland by a 73-year-old.
—Yes. The honourable member for Capricornia should go back to Queensland.
—Order! The two honourable members from northern areas will cease their by-play across the chamber and allow the Deputy Leader of the National Party to continue.
—Is it the intensity of the sun, Mr Speaker?
—I am not allowed to comment on those matters.

—I commend the Government for restoring soil conservation funding to its previous level, but I would prefer this legislation, which gives the statutory framework to the national soil conservation program, to have some reference to the basic levels of funding. I see this as a shortcoming in the legislation. The provisions for the recovery of moneys from recipients of Commonwealth payments as set out in clause 7 (4) (a) of the Bill are also of some concern. This clause empowers the Government to demand from any payee the equivalent amount of income derived from the acquisition or production of any property in the course of the conservation project or the equivalent income from any patents for inventions made in the course of the project. So restrictive is the nature of that provision that it is almost like something one would see in the Merchant of Venice. The aim of this legislation must be to promote the greatest possible conservation effort around Australia but the uncertainty created by the seemingly harsh provision might well act as a disincentive. I stress that the clause gives the Federal Government the ability to resume, not the actual property or income, but the income equivalent of any proceeds resulting from the work. The determination of this equivalent amount rests with the Minister or an authorised officer of the Minister. The measures do appear excessive, and I would urge the Minister to give consideration to further amendment which would at least clarify the Government's intentions in this regard.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also a need to spell out the extent to which the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee will control soil conservation funding in Australia. In particular, the Committee would appear to have power over the distribution of all funds, whether they be to States, to individual projects or to Commonwealth departments. There is a need for clarification of the extent to which this legislation may override the powers of the States. Neither the second reading speech nor the Bill really gives any clear indication of the extent to which the Commonwealth could override the powers, responsibilities, functions and experience of the State governments that have wrestled with the problem over many years. The primary responsibility of the State governments in soil conservation efforts must be maintained. The State governments are best equipped to carry out work on the important effort which has accelerated over the past decade. The role of the Commonwealth is essentially one of overseeing the national effort to promote the optimal use of available funds.

I wish to stress that the Opposition in no way attempts to denigrate the national soil conservation program, which is a commendable effort to assist the efforts of the States and of those associated with the land to overcome a serious national problem. Apart from the reservations I have made, the Opposition will not oppose the legislation. I do make some commitment on the part of the Opposition parties. We are seriously concerned about soil conservation in this nation. In a period of the Fraser Government it was resolved to build the amount into the States grants program but we decided that the States, probably under pressure for the use of resources available to them, would divert those resources to other causes. I think it has been a lesson to governments in the Commonwealth area that in future we must never depart from a direct responsibility in the area of soil conservation.
