TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the attention of the House to the state of hospital queues in Victoria. On 29 March the Australian Medical Association indicated that about 20,000 patients were awaiting admission to public hospitals. Last week the Victorian Minister for Health was prepared to admit that 21,838 people were on hospital waiting lists in Victoria, and worse is to come. It is interesting to look at the comparison. In 1982, pre-Medicare and pre-Cain, 9,000 patients were waiting for a bed in a hospital. After Minister Roper, and now Minister White, and after Medicare, that figure has more than doubled to 21,838.

SPEECH.PARA: When Medicare was introduced the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) sent a letter to all Australians indicating that Medicare would be simpler, cheaper, fairer and that the previous scheme was too expensive and too complicated. How about the feelings of those 20,000 or more people in the queue waiting to get a hospital bed? If we look at the figures in detail we see that in September 1984 about 4,000 patients were waiting to receive orthopaedic surgery such as hip replacement or surgery to the knees. Some 900 patients required eye treatment. They had problems with cataracts and were technically blind yet they could not get into hospitals in Victoria. Some 1,800 children were denied a hospital bed. What is more, the statistics do not really indicate the true position because a number of people have given up hope of ever getting into a public hospital in Victoria. I guess that the number of people on the waiting list would be more than 21,000.

The position in Victoria is that the public hospitals are full. There is a shortage of beds and a shortage of nurses. The Victorian Minister for Health agreed with that in his Press release. Operating theatres are full and there is a lack of funds. It has been reliably estimated that we need between $54m and $500m for capital and recurrent expenditure just to fix up that sector of hospitals in Australia. The private hospitals are underutilised. Fewer patients are privately insured, and that has come about because the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) has attempted to nationalise health care in Australia. He has attempted to nationalise doctors and hospital treatment. I refer to the position in New South Wales, where orthopaedic surgeons have resisted very strongly the nationalisation of health care.

In the present situation where many Australians actually go into hospital they are quite amazed at the cost of hospital care. If they have no insurance, they have to join the queue. If by chance they get into a private hospital they are amazed at the quite horrific costs. They have been led to believe by propaganda that this would never happen to them. The ratio of public patients in city hospitals has moved from 60 per cent to 80 per cent. This has come about because private patients are under the impression that they can claim under Medicare when they should have paid their way and used private hospitals. They are now clogging up the public hospitals and denying treatment to genuine public patients.

Medicare costs have escalated by some $250m from February 1984 to June 1984. That occurred in the very early days of the Medicare scheme. The situation in Victorian hospitals is even more of a problem in that in 1983-84 there was a 1.5 per cent Budget cut. That cut affected hospitals in the financial year 1984-85. To meet these Budget cuts wards were closed, there were fewer patients and fewer services were provided. Imagine the problems the organisation of admissions to public hospitals would cause to staff morale. What criteria do they use in a life and death situation when deciding on allowing patients to be admitted? Hospital managers are leaving, and there are difficulties all around. I have it on reliable authority from a doctor colleague of mine that the only way to get a patient into a public hospital in Victoria is to put that patient in an ambulance and to circulate the suburbs making radio contact with various hospitals until that patient gains entry.

In the case of the regional city of Ballarat, there is a waiting list at the base hospital, but in the private hospital there are empty, spare beds. An administrator of high reputation in that city indicated to me that there is no chance of the queues ever being reduced unless there is a radical change to the total system; that is, a total rejection of the current Medicare arrangements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to draw the attention of the House to the operations of one of the most important public organisations in Australia. I refer to the Surf Life Saving Association of Australia. Early in January 1907, two boys were washed out to sea at Sydney's Bondi Beach and for the first time a surf reel was used as a means of rescue. One of the youngsters saved that day was Charles Smith of Neutral Bay, who was brought ashore in a serious condition. That same Charles Smith lost his life at sea somewhere in the Indian Ocean in November 1935, on a flight from England to Australia. He was known then as the pioneering aviator Sir Charles Kingsford Smith.

SPEECH.PARA: The origins of the Surf Life Saving Association of Australia can be traced to those early days of this century, when small groups of experienced surfers began to form themselves into life-saving bodies as the dangers of surfing became apparent. Since 1907, there have been well in excess of 281,000 recorded rescues carried out by the surf lifesavers. Today, the Association has 15,258 volunteer surf lifesavers around the Australian coastline. The type of reel, line and belt used to rescue Charles Smith is still being used on beaches today, but little could the famous aviator have known that in the 1980s aviation would be playing a major role in surf rescue. Today, the use of helicopters has revolutionised surf rescue techniques and provides a vital service in several States of Australia.

In recent weeks, a new era dawned in surf live-saving helicopter rescue services with the re-launching of the Illawarra IBM-SLSA helicopter rescue service in my electorate. The Association has now completely restructured its operational systems and in future the national and State levels will play a far greater role in organisation, staff and financial support. The SLSA presently operates nine helicopter rescue aircraft, and this month Sydney will launch a highly sophisticated twin-engined helicopter. Other craft operate from Western Australia, Victoria, Newcastle, New South Wales North Coast, Queensland Gold Coast and Queensland Sunshine Coast. Although the craft remain involved in surf rescue, they now are called upon to carry out numerous other rescues in the bush, from cliff faces and in the open sea. They also carry out search and rescue work, medical support operations and medical evacuations, and assist police and other statutory authorities.

Rescue helicopter crewmen are specifically selected lifesavers who are trained to meet the rigorous requirements involved. Applicants must be 18 years of age, have an SLSA bronze qualification and have completed three seasons on beach patrol duties. They must also hold a current SLSA advanced resuscitation certificate, or current SLSA radio operator's certificate, a current Red Cross or St John Ambulance basic first aid certificate, and be proficient in snorkel diving to a depth of three metres. But these are only basic requirements, and on entry into the service further training in advanced first aid, resuscitation and rescue techniques is undertaken. The crewmen are volunteers who are backed up by a highly trained, competent group of pilots, many of whom are former senior military pilots who have attained more than 8,000 hours flying helicopters. Together they make a most formidable team.

I would be remiss if I did not mention the role private sponsors play in keeping this vital service available to the surfing public of Australia. Westpac Banking Corporation has long been associated with the Sydney rescue service, and in the 1983-1985 seasons Westpac contributed $1.5m to its operation. Governments, radio and television stations and corporate grants all provide further necessary funding. In the case of the Illawarra service, the Illawarra Mutual Building Society has been generous over several years. Finally, I pay tribute to the memory of Mr Tom Thompson, a crewman with the Illawarra service who gave his life in service to the community last October. Tom was the crewman flying a woman injured in a car accident to a Sydney hospital when his craft crashed. In a small tribute to his memory and dedication, the new aircraft proudly bears his name.

SPEECH.PARA: I was not satisfied with the decision of the local manager, so I wrote to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) on 5 February to ask him to intervene to ensure that Mr Hummerstone could be employed. I received no reply from the Minister, so I wrote again on 13 March. Again, he did not reply to that follow-up letter of 13 March, so I sent the Minister a telegram on 4 April. I have still not had a reply to any of those representations to the Minister. In those circumstances I cannot accept the rhetoric from Government Ministers when they say that they are concerned about unemployed youth. In those circumstances my representations to the Minister have been totally ignored. I regret that I had to raise this matter in the House. Under normal circumstances this young lad should be permitted to work by the Department and at least the Minister could have the courtesy to give me a reply to my representations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I express concern in the House tonight on behalf of a number of small business people in my electorate who have contacted me about penalties being imposed by the Australian Taxation Office for the late payment of group tax.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset, let me pay tribute to small business in Australia. It is the small business that provides our industries with skilful entrepreneurship and innovations. It is also the small business that provides the greater number of jobs, as it is short of capital and therefore more labour intensive. Australian industry is built on inventiveness and the ability of small business and small enterprises. I represent an electorate that embraces more than 2,000 small factories and workshops and I know the value of the contribution of small business to our economy. Yet, this is not readily acknowledged by the Taxation Office.

My constituents are irate at having to lodge written complaints, obtain bank statements and contact their local member of parliament because they are being penalised for late payment of tax when their cheques have been delayed-either in the mail or as a result of the go slow in the Taxation Office-by circumstances beyond their control. Indeed, many firms in Victoria may be unknowingly paying fines when, in fact, their group tax was forwarded with a reasonable expectation that it would reach the Taxation Office within seven days of the end of each month-the due date for this tax. I understand that the Taxation Office has recently stipulated that it must actually receive these payments within the seven days of the end of the month. I am not talking about those firms that post their cheques on the seventh day. My concern is expressed on behalf of those conscientious people who make every effort to comply, to avoid penalties by making their payments within a reasonable time and who are being penalised by intractable bureaucracy.

Whilst I am, of course, happy to assist people and I urge the many small firms in my electorate who are experiencing problems of this kind to contact me, it does appear that this is unnecessary and unreasonable persecution by the devotees of red tape. In one case, Mr Albert Blashki of Ace Wireworks told me that he wrote a cheque on 21 December 1984 and mailed it on 3 January 1985 and then received a letter from the Taxation Office telling him that he would be required to pay a $114 penalty for late payment. I have had letters from other firms and I heard of a similar case on a talk-back radio program in Melbourne recently. I have rung the Deputy Commissioner's Office and I am confident that these cases will be resolved and the penalties will be retracted.

I know through my dealings with the Taxation Office in the past how helpful the personnel are and as far as I can remember, most problems of my constituents have been resolved satisfactorily. I especially want to pay tribute to the Commissioner's clerks, who in every case have courteously assisted me with my constituents' problems. However, I would like to see a more flexible attitude being adopted by bureaucracy and I hope that this particular intransigence in the Department will be overcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

—The honourable member's Government did it; it is his Government's action that has caused it. I have had a succession of elderly Australians, men and women, ex-servicemen-and it is Anzac Day only next week-coming to me. One ex-serviceman who fought for five years for this country came to see me with tears in his eyes because he had no income and his pension was taken away completely because he wanted the privilege of living on his own land. That was his crime. He wanted to stay on his own land.
—That is a right, not a privilege.

—Yes, it is a right. And for that his pension has been taken away completely. He has no income. He has no money to pay the rates. It is all right for honourable members on the other side and for the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), who unfortunately is not here tonight, to quote examples of people who have $700,000 and suggest that it is unjust that they should receive the pension. What is wrong is that ordinary Australian men and women are being pushed into poverty. For all the examples of the millionaires, whoever they might be--

—Order! The honourable member for Perth is going beyond the bounds of tolerance.

—I note with pleasure that the Minister for Social Security has entered the chamber because it is important that he understand that we are not talking about rich people. —I suggest that at 79 these elderly Australians have done something good for the nation. I suggest that ex-servicemen and women in their seventies and eighties have already done their share. How dare you suggest that they should go out to work in their seventies and eighties. You uncaring person.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to see every caring man and woman in this country write to his or her Federal member or to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I would like them to spend 33c on a stamp to express their disgust and dissatisfaction with the assets test. We have just gone through an election and it is too long to wait for the next election. We need to get ordinary men and women in this country to join with us to swamp the Minister or the Prime Minister with letters of appeal, with pleas for them to take note of the injustice and the frightful conditions that so many elderly Australians are being thrust into. —If we can marshal the resources of caring Australians to write to members of this Parliament, to make the point that in circumstances where elderly Australians are living on land in rural areas, are losing their pensions and have no income, that we ask and beg the Minister and the Prime Minister to really reconsider and do something about it. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legal challenge presently being mounted by a British born computer expert, Dr Cliff Johnson, against the United States of America Defense Department and the Secretary of Defense, Mr Caspar Weinberger, brings to the attention of us all once again the lunacy of nuclear deterrence policies. Films and books have dealt with the theme of a nuclear war being launched by accident but the possible court case is a reality and the facts it deals with are a reality.

SPEECH.PARA: On 3 June 1980 the Strategic Air Command centre in Omaha was alerted by its radar screens to incoming Soviet nuclear missiles. The strategic nuclear bomber force was alerted, US nuclear submarines patrolling the oceans of the world were also alerted and the countdown towards a massive nuclear weapons retaliation had begun before, after several minutes, it was realised that the computer-relayed information about the incoming Soviet missiles was false. The subsequent inquiry found that the cause of the error was a malfunctioning computer chip in the communications systems which provided the information to the radar screens of the Strategic Air Command. Although similar incidents had not been recorded prior to June 1980, officials of the North American air defence complex were reported as saying that such malfunctions can occur two or three times a year as a result of random failures within the computers which are an essential part of the nuclear defence warning system.

Dr Johnson's main case rests on his contention that the US nuclear defence policy is based on a launch on warning capability or LOW-another of those diabolical disingenuous acronyms. Nuclear deterrence systems programmed for LOW are systems which are effectively controlled by a super computer, but, charged Dr Johnson, they are not controlled by the President of the United States of America as required by its Constitution. Assuming that a nuclear war began in Western Europe, while a Pershing II missile takes six minutes to reach Moscow, the Soviet SS-22 missiles can take less than three minutes to reach Frankfurt or Bonn. As Dr Johnson points out, it is impossible for the USA to give a human response in three minutes. A human being would need one minute to check on the reality of the warning signal and another minute to track down the President. The remaining minute would leave insufficient time to launch the retaliatory strike and so, concluded Dr Johnson, the USA nuclear defence system must be programmed for a computer launch of a retaliatory nuclear counter-strike missile to reach a Soviet target before the Soviet missile had reached its target. Of course, with the secrecy that surrounds all such military operations it is necessary to work painstakingly and logically through the options open to the Defense Department, as Dr Johnson has done.

In the case of the Star Wars weapons system development the situation is even more ludicrous because space-based laser beam weapons would have only a 90-second warning to counter a Soviet missile attack and it is difficult to see how such a system could become retaliatory without the use of a computer. The USA Defense Department has, predictably, argued that Dr Johnson's charges are not for the court to decide. Sensitive national security and foreign policy matters should be decided by the people's elected representatives, argued the Defense Department. I am an elected representative of the Australian people and I do not want to be part of any nuclear defence system, whether such a system is controlled by a computer or otherwise. But what choice do I have? While successive Australian governments refuse, on the grounds of national security, to inform the Australian people of the part we play in the nuclear deterrence systems of the USA, how can I keep my constituents informed of the risks for Australia in providing bases for such facilities? I think we have the right to know these things when the lives of ourselves and our families may rest on whether a computer circuit has malfunctioned.

In 1983 the US Defense advanced research projects agency began work on a multi-million dollar development for a military super computer. The problem for Dr Johnson, and any other individual who uses legal arguments to challenge the wisdom of nuclear weapons, is to establish that those weapons are causing that person injury. However, a quote from Dr Cliff Johnson himself provides the best answer to the obvious question: Would such a computer fail? Easily, says Dr Johnson, as computer reliability professionals talk in terms of failure rates, never of infallibility; and although electronic elements are becoming more reliable, failure rates per chip are rising due to the more rapid increase in the number of elements per chip. Such arguments cannot get away from the fact that, with such small time intervals, whichever super-power is involved, whether it is the USSR or the USA, the malfunctioning of a defence systems computer resulting in a nuclear war is a very real and frightening prospect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am an elected representative of the people of Australia and I take a completely opposite view to that of my friend the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton). Tasmania is a lovely little place. It has 400,000 people and is very peaceful but it always seems to attract all the agitators. Everybody who has an axe to grind always seems to want to go down to Tasmania and do so. That is probably due to the media coverage of Tasmania. One television station covers the whole of Tasmania, so when an esteemed person such as Senator Chipp goes down there and expresses a particular opinion about nuclear war and American warships coming into Tasmania, what he says gets coverage all over Tasmania. The USS Texas came into the port of Hobart today and the same old protesters-about 20 people-were down there expressing their beliefs. The media give them a heck of a lot of coverage, but the majority of Tasmanians never have an opportunity to express their beliefs. Many Tasmanians welcome the visit of the USS Texas.

SPEECH.PARA: I think my friend across the room misses the most important point of this argument, and that is that America is always being condemned. It is very much in vogue today for young people to be taught to condemn America but very little is said about Russia. Palm Sunday is the day for peace and the day we all go to whichever church we want and express what we believe about world peace. None of us wants a nuclear war but we have to be sensible about it. On that day a peace protest was held at New Norfolk, which is 22 miles from Hobart. An advertisement was put out by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics-Australia Society supporting that rally. I noticed that there were no peace protesters who were protesting against the USSR. America is always being condemned. What worries me is that the media are giving saturation coverage to this point of view and people are starting to wonder what is going on. Even in the schools in Hobart at the moment the children are being taught that America-never Russia-is at fault. I think we had better start waking up in Australia before we are saturated to such a degree that the next generation will believe that we depend on the USSR, not America. We need to be sensible about it and to express our views at every opportunity.

Every time there is a peace and disarmament group gathering it contains many well-intentioned people. Many of them believe in peace and want peace. We all want it. Always the signatories to those protests are left wing unionists, the Communist Party of Australia, the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia and the USSR-Australia Society. We are being conned in Australia by these groups of people who seem to believe that that is the only way to achieve peace in the world today. They should be told that in Australia there are many people who believe we were saved by America. I welcome the USS Texas to Hobart and all other members from Tasmania welcome it. A group of Tasmanians rang me today and asked: 'Bruce, can we use your name in a protest against the protesters who do not want the USS Texas to come into a Tasmanian port?' We welcome the Americans. We know that they saved us. It was not the Russians who saved us and it is not the Russians who fight for peace in this universe. They are the ones we need to fight. I think my friend over there had better get his facts right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a matter which I believe is of importance to many Australians and I relate my remarks to the question of road safety, specifically as it refers to young cyclists. I want to target my comments on the use of helmets by cyclists. It is of great regret that many young people today are not prepared to wear helmets, mainly because it is not the done thing. They see the use of such road safety measures as sissy and not the macho sort of image that one ought to have. There is also the question of cost. A recent study showed that the helmets that are available to young people can cost anywhere between $20 and $100. Some consideration has been given to their effectiveness. Some recent studies have shown that they are not worth the money. So we face a problem in that we have young people who, for a start, are not aware of the importance of protecting themselves, and we have the problem of families not being able to afford this very important safety measure. We also have the problem of manufacturers producing a product which, in itself, is of little use.

SPEECH.PARA: We need a nationwide campaign, first and foremost to create some awareness. It may well be that we need to draw upon the reputations of well-known cyclists and that we need to provide funds not only at a Federal level, as has been done by this Government, but at a State level to encourage our service clubs in the various electorates to undertake a program, the objective of which should be not to provide finance for helmets but, in the first instance, to change attitudes.

Recent statistics are hard to find because too often when a child on a bike is knocked down by a car that fact does not appear on statistical forms. Unless the child is seriously injured one often hears little more about it. But recently in central Queensland a young girl was killed. There have been a number of injuries in country areas. This matter does not relate just to the cities. I stress that in any one week in any year, about one million Australians are riding bikes. These people are at risk.

We need a nationwide awareness and promotion campaign. That campaign ought to involve not just government but those relevant groups within the community. We need to involve the schools, and to seek the support of law enforcement agencies, not in some Big Brother approach but on an educational line. Such a campaign has to be co-ordinated. It is not just a matter of the use of helmets, as we saw recently in Queensland, where the Road Ahead came out with an excellent article. It is a matter of bringing together the expertise available, seeking the support of media, whether it be radio, television or the newspapers, and asking them to join in the campaign that could begin here tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good idea. We are talking about it now on the Road Safety Committee.

—It is a beginning, but the end is a long way down the track because of the points I have made, first, about cost. I stress that the main question is one not of cost but of attitude. Whilst I welcome the point made by the honourable member, I must say that unless we, as members of parliament, can convince our own community groups, the decision-makers within our various areas, to join with us in this campaign, we will achieve little.

SPEECH.PARA: It was 10 years ago, I recall, that the issue was raised in Queensland and a campaign was started. I suggest that if honourable members visited schools in Queensland, let alone schools in their own electorates, they would find very few young people who are prepared, this day, to wear helmets. One per cent would be an optimistic figure.

This is a matter of major concern to me as in recent times I have seen a young person who was injured seriously-fortunately, not killed-not because of a mad motorist but simply because of a rush coming out of school without due care and attention. In the hustle and bustle that occurs between three and four o'clock of an afternoon in most towns and cities throughout the nation, a motorist unfortunately hit this cyclist. The child was injured because that child was not wearing a helmet. I urge a new approach, a new attitude. Present attitudes can be changed by a nationwide awareness campaign, a campaign that ought to start here.

Alternatively, it is possible for people to seek an independent valuation.

I also remind the House of the hardship provisions that are part of the assets test legislation and which go specifically to the kinds of circumstances described by the honourable member for Cowper. I make the point that the hardship provisions go to the very case where it is impossible for people to achieve an income from a significant asset. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 22 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is any cost-benefit analysis being undertaken of the millions of dollars invested in royal commissions, task forces and the other related inquiries into organised crime.
(2) Apart from the public revelations, how much new information has been discovered by these inquiries which had not been known already to the police.

(3) Is it a fact that (a) the final report of the Special Prosecutor, Mr Redlich, expressed the gravest concern about the gross incapacity of the Australian Federal Police to deal with crime, (b) there is growing evidence across the world that police are becoming more efficient at crowd control and the containment of demonstrations, that require little or no community relations, than at the prevention and detection of crime, that are impossible without community relations and (c) there is an apparent correlation between the increasing numbers of police and the declining rates of crime clearance; if so, does he have a plan for researching police operations to improve performance.

(4) Is it also a fact that the operations of the National Crime Authority will involve it with a variety of reportedly ineffective criminal justice systems at all levels across the country; if so, what steps are being taken by the Government to avoid the millions of dollars being spent on the Authority being wasted by expecting the Authority to achieve the impossible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am not aware that any specific cost-benefit analysis has been undertaken. Indeed Mr Costigan observed, in his Final Report, that much of the benefit of these inquiries lies in the disclosure of criminal organisations and their activities, a benefit to society as a whole which cannot be quantified. Nevertheless it is possible to quote relevant figures for some police Joint Task Forces. In the case of the Commonwealth/NSW Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking for example, over 200 alleged offenders have been apprehended since April 1979 most of them in connection with the supply, importation or use of heroin.

As a result, the Joint Task Force has broken up 16 major heroin importation groups and 9 minor groups supplying heroin, Indian hemp and cocaine. Up to mid-1984, the Australian Taxation Office, acting on information from the Joint Task Force, had recovered $4,728,000 as understated income and additional taxation penalties, and $300,000 had been recovered by way of forfeiture of bail and seizure of cash. Mr Costigan himself points out, on page 168 of the first volume of his Final Report, that, as a direct result of his Commission's activities, over $25 million of outstanding tax has been assessed. This compares with a cost of some $13 million for the Royal Commission.

(2) The powers of the Royal Commissions Act have enabled the Stewart and Costigan Royal Commissions to follow the 'paper trail' with considerable success, producing a significant flow of new information to police for follow-up investigations.

(3) (a) The former Special Prosecutor, Mr Redlich, in his Final Report said of the AFP: 'I again wish to record my appreciation of the support given to me generally by the Force and my satisfaction overall with the results achieved to date'. Mr Redlich did, however, remark on the need for 'a sustained and substantial injection of funds, further recruitment and training of investigative personnel and administrative support', if the AFP was to cope with the increasing demands made of it. In recognition of these needs the Government is committed to spending more than $7 million on upgrading the AFP's computer capacity and an additional $10 million on recruiting an even stronger force.

(b) I am not aware of any evidence suggesting that police worldwide are becoming more efficient at crowd control to the detriment of crime prevention and community relations. It is undoubtedly true that successful crime prevention depends greatly on close co-operation between the police and the community.

(c) I know of no evidence of such a correlation; nor is it clear how such evidence might be established. Mr Redlich, for example, refers in his Final Report to an increase in AFP members since 1979, and to the rapid increase in the rate of detected crime in areas for which the AFP is responsible. This is especially so in the area of fraud against Commonwealth Departments where investigations tend to be complex and time-consuming. The Government believes that its recent initiatives in the upgrading of the AFP-including implementation of the recommendations of a recent Joint Management Review-will improve the AFP's capacity to respond to the changing law enforcement environment. The establishment, in 1982, of the National Police Research Unit and the upgrading of the Australian Police College will also be beneficial to the performance of all Australian police forces.

(4) It is not for the Commonwealth to comment on the effectiveness of State criminal justice systems. I strongly dispute any suggestion that the National Crime Authority is a waste of money. While there are, of course, considerable difficulties in successfully fighting organised crime, that does not mean that the fight should be abandoned. The National Crime Authority was established to investigate organised crime, including drug trafficking, on a national basis-to deal particularly with offences which involve more than one jurisdiction and which are beyond ordinary police powers; matters which are unlikely to be resolved easily.
Importantly, the National Crime Authority is supported by all Australian Governments.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 25 February 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Between Australia and which other countries do international air rights exist
(2) Which of these rights are not being utilised and until when are each of these rights current

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Rights for the international airlines of other countries to operate services to Australia and for Qantas to operate services to those countries are generally embodied in Air Service Agreements which are documents of treaty status. Australia also has air service arrangements which are documents of less than treaty status and provide for the operation of direct air services between Australia and the following countries: Brunei, Solomon Islands, Tonga, Vanuatu, Western Samoa.

Services between Australia and Zimbabwe are operated in accordance with a permit issued by the Government of Zimbabwe which recognises the Commercial Agreement which exists between Qantas and Air Zimbabwe.

(2) Air service agreements or arrangements under which scheduled services are not currently conducted by either Australia or the relevant bilateral partner are: Austria, Burma, Egypt, Ireland, Lebanon, Sri Lanka, Tonga.
Rights granted in these dormant agreements or arrangements continue indefinitely unless termination provisions included in each agreement or arrangement are invoked by either party.
(3) The Government has received no application in recent times from the Governments of Austria, Burma, Ireland, Lebanon or Tonga to commence schedule passenger air services to Australia.

Representatives of the Government of Sri Lanka held informal discussions with officials in Canberra on 4 and 5 March 1985 on the possibility of re-establishing direct air services between Australia and Sri Lanka. The matter continues to be under consideration by both Governments.
